 1. BACKGROUND A. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of China (GOC) has requested World Bank assistance in financing a national seed commercialization project. The project would help develop a conducive environment for the development of a commercial seed sector through the adoption cf necessary policies and an appropriate regulatory framework. It would modernize, rationalize and commercialize a number of seed companies and strengthen the public seed sector so that it can provide effective services to farmers. It would provide support to several national and provincial seed organizations and would modernize seed companies from 14 provinces. The project aims ultimately to facilitate the development of a vibrant seed sector, which can not only provide increased amounts of quality seed to farmers but also operate through efficient and self-sustaining commercial enterprises. Incremental benefits would come from improved yield, lower sowing rates and reduced seed costs for major crops such as hybrid rice, hybrid maize, wheat, soybeans, cotton, vegetables and fruit trees. This in turn would increase farmer incomes and employment. The project was identified by a Food and Agriculture Organization/Cooperative Program (FAO/CP) mission and a World Bank team in November 1993 and prepared in May and November 1994. It was preappraised and then appraised by World Bank missions in April 1995 and September/October 1995. B. AGRICULTURAL SECTOR 1.2 Agriculture continues to play a major role in the Chinese economy. It is estimated that agriculture accoun s for 20 percent of GNP and provides employment for about 200 million farm families. Less than 15 percent of China's land area is arable, and farming systems are generaily very intensive with heavy inputs of labor and fertilizer. Nearly half the cropped area is irrigated. This intensive farming has enabled China to meet the great bulk of its basic food requirements. 1.3 As a result of policy reforms in the late 1970s-in particular the introduction of the household production responsibility system and the development of rural markets- the value of agricultural output grew at an impressive average of 6 percent per year over the period 1978-1990. The growth rate increased to over 7 percent during 1990-93 but declined substantially to 2.4 percent in 1994. Grain production, which ranged between 376-402 million tons during 1985-1988, was the Government's central agricultural concern during the late 1980s. Major efforts were made to increase grain production, and by the 1990s production had risen to a new plateau of around 450 million tons (435456 million tons between 1990-94).
 - 2 - 1.4 In 1994, the Government was concerned about the decline in rice and wheat output. The official estimates of paddy production were 189 million tons in 1990 but only 176 millic.n tons in 1994. Likewise, wheat production fell from 106 million ton in 1993 to 99 million tons in 1994. This has resulted in an increase in wheat and rice imports and a suspension in exports of rice and corn due to insufficient stocks. The nationwide inflation in 1993-94 combined witH "lagging commodity price management" placed farmers in a cost/price squeeze that discouraged fertilizer purchases and contributed-along with the bad weather-to the drop in agriculture production and a substantial decline in gross value of agricultural output in 1994. Since then, the government has improved its monetary policy to stabilize inflation and to maintain suitable terms of trade for grain production with respect to input prices. Farmers were able to farm more intensively with improved varieties of seeds, and output has increased. Grain production was reported to reach another record high of 466 million tons in 1995. C. BANK GROUP LENDING IN AGRICULTURE 1.5 Bank Group lending to China for agriculture is designed to support the government's efforts to increase and diversify agricultural production. Specific policy considerations include reforms designed to make government agencies more efficient and commercialize enterprises and services. Bank Group lending to date has comprised 43 operations, amounting to more than $6.2 billion and has covered a wide spectrum of geographic areas and subsectors, with major efforts in land development, irrigation and drainage, flood control (11 projects), upgrading of agricultural support services including agricultural research, extension, seed improvement (3 projects), development of specialized subsectors including forestry, fruit and fisheries (9 projects), agroindustry, credit, and logistics (8 projects), watershed rehabilitation and poverty alleviation (5 projects) and area development (7 projects). This lending has been designed to support the govemmeni's efforts to increase and diversify agricultural production through more efficient use of land, water, capital and labor and through the improvement of support services such as credit, research, extension and veterinary services. 1.6 Since 1987, the Bank Group has supported a series of provincial development projects in which an area development approach has been applied. The projects were designed to alleviate poverty and to assist the Government in its ongoing reform process. The Rural Seclor Adjustment Loan (Cr. 1932-CHA and Ln. 2967-CHA), which was approved during 1988, contributed to the articulation of the overall reform process, and involved the Bank Group in increasingly intensive policy dialogue in agriculture and poverty allevialion, sustained through the process of project development and several major sector stLdies (e.g., on grain, poverty alleviation, animal feed, the management of the Yellow River and marketing of agricultural crops) and project formulation exercises. 1.7 Implementation of most ongoing Bank Group-financed projects in the agriculture sector is on schedule. Experience in previous Bank Group agricultural projects in China is that physical works have been completed on time or ahead of schedule. Disbursements for agricultural projects, in fact, usually outpace those in other sectors. Notable features
 - 3 - of all the projects are the high standard of project management, the active participation of farmers and the effective collaboration of government authorities at all levels. Sixteen projects have been completed. The completion reports for these projects indicate that implementation was generally successful, that most economic rates of return reached or exceeded appraisal estimates, and that the technology used was sound and appropriate for wider application. 1.8 The Bank Group's current lending strategy in agriculture, while maintaining subsectoral development and poverty alleviation objectives, is putting greater emphasis on commercial development. The new projects under preparation such as the Animal Feed Project, the State Farms Commercialization Project and this project, all aim at strengthening the commercial orientation of these subsectors and enabling future private- sector participation. D. SEED SUBSECTOR 1.9 Advances in seed technology are one of the most important channels for improving productivity in agriculture. The government recognizes the crucial role of the seed industry in achieving national targets of grain production and agriculture production goals generally. For this reason, it sees as a major constraint the present structure of the seed sector, which allows low-productivity, low-quality, unresponsive, loss-making seed producers to persist. There is full recognition of the need for major steps in the direction of commercialization, if only to stop the drain on the budget from the need to cover seed company losses. Central government strategies, while ensuring seed supply to farmers, will also promote efficient seed commercialization. At the macro level, the Government aims to create a conducive environment to support the seed commercial development by drafting policy and regulatory reforms. Its policies are designed to promote seed-sector commercialization by shifting from an administrative hierarchy of seed companies (provincial, prefecture and county) to a competitive structure and by supporting efficient companies. At the enterprise level, it emphasizes high-quality and new-variety seeds, modernization of seed processing and packaging equipment and seed enterprise profitability. The success of commercialization strategies will be influenced by overall economic reform in China. In particular, it will be influenced by the overall reform program for state-owned enterprises (SOEs), since the sector is now dominated by jurisdictional seed companies and state farms. 1.10 The formal seed sector in China is large and complex. In 1993 there were more than 2,700 seed companies in China, one for almost every administrative division within the country. The companies are loosely networked in a pyramidal structure with the China National Seed Corporation (CNSC) at the apex. Beneath the CNSC, each of the 30 provinces has a provincial seed company, and below these are some 500 prefecture and 2,200 county seed companies. All the seed companies are state-owned enterprises known as executive/business management units. In addition there are 2,500 Township Seed Supply Stations (TSSS) owned by farmer collectives, whose main function is to distribute seeds to farmers. They are also responsible for organizing the production and local sale
 - 4 - of conventional (i.e., nonhybrid) seed of crops such as rice and wheat by farmer cooperatives. 1.11 The uset of seed produced by the organized sector has increased from about 1.3 million tons in 1976 to over 3.5 million tons in 1994. This is about 25 percent of the total annual seed requirement of about 12.5 million tons. The balance is met by the informal seed sector, i.e. by farmers' own seed or farmer-to-farmer sales. Given that conventional crops, such as wheat and self-pollinated rice, make up the bulk of crop production and that much of the area under these crops does not need new seed every year, the ratio of processed to farmer seed is reasonable. It is officially projected that in the year 2000 the total demand For seed will be 12.0 million tons (the reduction being due to reduced seeding rates and a reduction in the total sown area) and that the organized sector will supply about 44 percent of this demand. 1.12 In addition to the seed companies, a large number of state farms (SFs) and a few collective seed companies are also involved in the production of seed. While most SF seed production is for own use, a nunber of farms specialize in industrial crop seed production (e.g., sugar beet, cotton or oilseed rape) for sale to other state farms. At present there are a veiy limrited number of private seed companies due both to the general difficulty in establishing private sector enterprises and also to specific regulatory requirements in the seed sector. 1.13 1 he organization of agricultural seed activities in China can be summarized as follows: (a) Selection and Breeding: The selection and breeding of varieties is mainly done at agricultural research and educational institutions such as agricultural science academies and agricultural universities. Some seed companies are increasingly giving emphasis to selecting and breeding their own varieties. There are no restrictions in this area, and individuals and collective entities are also encouraged to carry out breeding. (b) Adaptation and Regional Trials: Trials are jointly organized by the national and provincial agricultural research institutions and seed administration stations in the provinces. Any new promising line has to un-crgo tv. o to three years regional adaptability trials and one to two years field production trials for consideration for registration and approval for release. (c) Variety Examination: Evaluation of trial results is done at national, provincial or prefectural/municipality level by the respective crop variety examination committees, which comprise members from local governments, seed administrations, and research and academic institutions. A promising candidate line, which possesses definite quality advantages over existing varieties, will be awarded a variety certificate, registered and announced by the agricultural department at the corresponding administrative level.
 - 5 - (d) Seed Production: Seed production is mainly managed by county seed companies and state fanns and is done in their own seed production bases. Early generations are produced in state stock seed farms. Hybrids of important crops are only produced by government designated companies. Townships and individuals also produce seed in their seed production bases mainly for use in their own administrative areas. (e) Seed Marketing and Distribution: Seed companies are still the main marketing channels in China, and hybrids of important crops are marketed only by the designated companies that produce them. Conventional seed and vegetable seed are marketed through different channels, and collectives and individuals are allowed to trade in these seeds. The basic requirement for marketing seed is to obtain a seed business operation permit from the local seed station and the permit in turn is used to obtain a business operation license issued by the local Industrial and Commercial Administration office. Since 1992, the Ministry of Agriculture, through regulations on producing and marketing crop seed and animal vaccines by agricultural, scientific, research and educational units, has pemitted research and educational institutions to produce and market all kinds of crop seed. (f) Seed Quality Inspection and Quarantine: Seed quality inspection is enforced by the Department of Agriculture seed administration stations at the county level and above. Quarantine inspection is done by the Administration of Animal and Plant Quarantine Services at its 280 border and port/airport district and subdistrict stations in all the provinces and autonomous regions. Seed Industry Structure 1.14 Seed companies are primarily responsible to government agencies at their administrative levels. Thus the China National Seed Corporation is responsible to the Department of Agriculture (DOA) of the Ministry of Agriculture, the Provincial Seed Companies (PSCs) are responsible to the provincial Departments of Agriculture, and similarly at prefecture, municipal and county levels. 1.15 The lines of command and responsibility for the state farms vary somewhat from province to province, but at the national level, the Bureau of State Farms within MOA has overall responsibility. An organogram indicating the organizational structure of the seed industry and its position within MOA is provided in Figure 1. Regulatory Agencies And Institutions 1.16 MOA has four main agencies concemed directly with seed regulations and policy, as follows:
 - 6 - (a) DOA Seed Division (SD): This unit is responsible for drafting seed laws, regulations, plans and policies and for supervising seed management. (h) National Agricultural Technical Extension Service Center (NATESC): The National Seed Administration Station and the Plant Protection Station became part of a new National Agricultural Technical Extension Service Center (NATESC). Seed activities are grouped into three divisions within the center-the Seed Industry Management Division, the Seed Testing Division (which contains the National Seed Testing Center) and the Variety Trial and Seed Multiplication Division. These Divisions are responsible for the implementation of seed extension and national seed security, application of new technologies and methods of seed production and seed processing, control and regulation of the seed industry and seed quality, and vocational training. The provincial, prefectural and county seed administration stations, however, have not been reorganized as part of their respective extension services. (c) National Crop Variety Examination and Approval Committee Office (NCVEACO): This unit is responsible for coordinating, supervising, examining and registering new varieties at the national level. Registration of new crop varieties at the provincial level is carried out by the provincial CVEACO. (d) Adwinistration of Animal and Plant Quarantine Services (AAPQS): This is anothler MOA executing unit that is responsible for quarantine in the international exchange of plants and animals. 1.17 Ir. addition, the National Patent Office through the patent law is responsible for the prot'ction of new plant varieties by pa.enting their breeding methodologies. Apvlications for patent are coordinated by the Patent Division of the MOA Department of Science, Technology and Quality Standardization in Beijing. Seed Companies 1.18 China National Seed Corporation (CNSC). CNSC was incorporated into MOA in 1982 with responsibility for planning, coordinating and distributing domestic seed production and the import and export of all seed. CNSC is an integrated company, involved in research, production and trade with more than 40 subsidiaries and joint ventures. The main seeds produced by these in eight provinces are: vegetables (200 tons in 1993), melon, hybrid maize (150,000 tons) and rice (2,000 tons), cotton, jute, oilseeds, herbs and flowers. It owns 46 retail outlets in China and has trading arrangements with more than 80 clients in 40 countries worldwide. In 1992, under the market reform program, CNSC became an autonomous seed trading company. It no longer has responsibility for administrative planning of domestic seed production, nor does it have a monopoly on exports and imports. It remains involved in seed policy-making at the national level and in the coordination of the seed trade among the provinces.
 1.19 Provincial Seed Companies (PSCs). In general the PSCs are responsible for preparing annual provincial seed development prograns and plans, which provide guidance for lower-level seed companies. Until recently they were also exclusively able to undertake interprovincial trade in seeds. The PSCs concentrate on the multiplication of breeder seed obtained from research academies or universities. Breeding material, previously supplied free, is now paid for either by outright purchase or by the payment of royalties. Some PSCs have established joint ventures with overseas companies to produce special high-value seeds, usually horticultural crops for export. 1.20 Prefectural/Municipal Seed Companies (MSCs). The main responsibility of the MSCs is to produce foundation seed from the breeder seed supplied by the PSCs. Most MSCs also produce breeder seed, production or certified seed, and many specialize in producing seed of particular crops. Seed is produced on production bases selected and supervised by the MSCs. A considerable number of MSCs have processing plants to clean, grade and pack seeds. 1.21 County Seed Companies (CSCs). These are the backbone of the Chinese seed industry, being responsible for the production of certified seed from foundation seed supplied by the MSCs. Commercial seed is actually produced by farmers under contract to Village Committees, which are usually organized into production bases by agrotechnical extension stations (ATES). Contracts detail the price to be paid for the seed, the quantity to be supplied, the procurement time and penalties for failure to meet requirements. CSCs are responsible for ensuring the supply of inputs (foundation seed, maternal and paternal parent seed for hybrids, fertilizer and pesticides). Inputs are generally supplied on credit, but at full cost. However in some cases such as fertilizer for hybrid rice seed, the price is subsidized. The CSCs provide technical advice to growers and are responsible for monitoring the seed crop for certification purposes. CSCs undertake seed processing and testing according to the standards and quality of their facilities. 1.22 State Farm Seed Companies. State farm seed companies are usually subfarms or teams within the administration of state farms, most lacking independent financial accounts. Normally, these seed producers have no official relationship with seed companies under the agiicultural system. However, they also sell their surplus seed in nearby farm markets. Specialty seed may be supplied to a much wider area. 1.23 Informal Seed Sector. It is reported that about 20-25 percent of the seeds produced in China for self-pollinating crops of conventional varieties are obtained from seed companies/extension stations while the rest (75-80 percent) are seeds saved by farmers for planting the next crop. Except for local specialty crops, there appears to be virtually no direct marketing of seeds by farmers-production is either strictly for own use or umder contractuai arrangements with the seed companies. 1.24 Private Seed Sector. Private seed companies do not really exist at present. A few county seed companies and research institutes have spun off snall subsidiaries that
 - 8 - produce seed of high value crops such as hybrid grain seeds, vegetables and horticulture crops and have an ownership structure that includes some private parties, mostly through worker sharehiolding. Almost all have other activities in addition to producing and marketing seeds, and most are profitable. The number and size of these companies will probably increase in the future due to continuing increase in the demand for vegetables and thus vegetable seeds. The area under vegetable production is now estimated at 4.5 million ha or 3 percent of the area under crops, requiring about 1.2 million tons of vegetable seed each year. E. SEED TECHNOLOGY AND PERFORMANCE 1.25 Rice. In the 1970s, the Chinese Government searched for solutions to the prevailing food grain shortages that had resulted from increasing population and stagnant grain yield. Rice, wheat and corn were chosen for research and development due to their potential for increased yields. The first hybrid rice was identified in 1974, and by 1975, hybrid rice was ready to be released for commercial production. The parent lines were from the best selected local varieties and imported ones from the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) and Thailand. Initially, the average seed yield of hybrid rice seed farms was low (0.4 tiha) but by 1991 the average yield of seed was 2.25 t/ha. In some areas, it has reached 4-5 t/ha.' The great improvement in hybrid rice seed production was due to the development of efficient seed production methods, improved parent lines and a good production system. The Government has used its information systems to create awareness of the existence and benefits of hybrid seed among farmers. Responsibility was assigned to one or more officials at each level to monitor the progress of adoption of hybrid rice, which was promoted by training and extension. Demonstration plots were emphasized. 1.26 The farm yield of hybrid rice increased from 4.2 t/ha in 1976 to 5.5 t/ha in 1991. The area under hybrid rice increased from 0.1 million ha in 1976 to 15.4 million ha in 1991, representing 45 percent of the total rice production area. The government plans to increase the area under hybrid rice by another 10 percent by the year 2000 and to increase the farm yield to 6-7.5 tlha. To achieve this high yield, China will need new germplasm from international sources. 1.27 Wheat is the second major grain crop after rice, occupying about 29 million ha per year with a total output of 99 million tons in 1994. Spring wheat, accounting for 17 percent of the total area, is planted in March-April and harvested in July and is largely a single crop. ][t is grown in the north of China in Heilongjiang, Jilin, Liaoning, Inner Mongolia, Gansu, Xinjiang and other provinces. Winter wheat, accounting for 83 percent of the sown wheat area, is planted in late September and harvested in mid-June. Average seed yields are always lower than the grain yields of farns using that seed, inter alia, due to the need to reject much unpure seed production.
 -9- Depending on the availability of irrigation water, double cropping of wheat followed by com, millet, beans and other cash crops is practiced. Production of winter wheat is concentrated in 5 zones: North China, Upper Yellow River, Yangtze River, Southwest, and South Chine. 1.28 Wheat yields increased moderately, from 2.8 t/ha in 1984 to 3.4 t/ha in 1994, because of improved varieties of seed, which are early maturing and have better resistance to disease, drought and cold. For example, cold resistant varieties (Fengkang and CA837) have marginally improved yields in the northern region (21 percent over the last 10-year period). But the development of still better varieties through research and development should be a priority because wheat imports have been increasing due to increases in domestic demand and lagging production. 1.29 Corn is the third main grain of China, after rice and wheat. In 1994, the corn sown area was 21 million hectares (18.7 percent of the country's grain sown area), and total corn production was 99 million tons, accounting for 22.3 percent of the country's total grain production of 445 million tons. Most of the production is located in the north and northeast regions, which has 70 percent of the sown area and 85 percent of total production. The country's average corn yield is 4.7 t/ha, 15 percent higher than the average grain yield of 4.1 t/ha 1.30 The increase in China's corn production has mainly been due to improved hybrid varieties, such as Dan Yu and Yie Tan, which have "compact" seed. The development of hybrid corn began in the 1950s. Double cross was introduced in the 1960s and single cross in the 1970s. The development and popularization of compact hybrid corn seed alone resulted in a yield increment of 1.5 t/ha. In 1965, hybrid com accounted for about 10 percent of the com sown area, and the average yield was 1 tlha. The area sown to hybrid corn progressively expanded to 79 percent by 1975 and 90 percent by 1994, and the corn yield increased to 3.6 t/ha in 1975 and 4.7 ttha in 1994. The average yield differs significantly by region, ranging from 5.3 t/ha in the northem region (Jilin, Liaoning and Heilongjiang) to 3 t/ha in the southem region (Sichuan, Yunnan and Guizhou). Corn breeders believe that average yields could be increased to 6.5 t/ha, if they could get arctcss to improved breeding materials. The aim is to produce seeds with high but stable yield and disease and pest tolerance. Better water supplies and inputs would aiso contribute to increased production.
 - 10- 2. SEED SECTOR DEVELOPMENT A. HISTORICAL BACKGROUND 2.1 After the establishment of the People's Republic, food production was the principal concern of the Chinese Government and seed development was given priority. In 1949 the Government established a Seed Division within the Ministry of Food to plan and manage tho supply of seed in the country. The separate Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) was given the responsibility for variety evaluation and recommendation, and the results were transferred to the Food Ministry for implementation. In 1958, due to the lack of seed technicians in the Food Ministry, all responsibilities for seed, encompassing administrative, techlical and business functions, were transferred to MOA. 2.2 In 1978, the China National Seed Corporation (CNSC) was set up to plan, coordinate and distribute domestic seed and handle overseas dealings. It was also known as the National Seed Bureau. Seed stations, which had the combined responsibilities of seed administrations and seed companies, were also set up. In 1980, the State Council issued a decree to separate the administrative functions of the CNSC from its business activities. The separation was achieved in 1982, resulting in the establishment of the MOA Seed Division (SD) and the National Seed Administration Station (NSAS). In 1991 the National Crop Variety Examination and Approval Committee Office (NCVEACO) was formed to be responsible for new variety evaluation. 2.3 The development of the Chinese seed industry can be broadly divided into three phases: (a) the period 1950-1977 when all seed sector activities were service oriented and profit was not to be mentioned; (b) the period 1978-1989, when seed companies were established, allowed to make minimal profits, and encouraged to produce seeds in which they had a cornparative advantage; and (c) the period 1990-present, which marks the beginning of seed market liberalization. Seed market liberalization started with removal of CNSC monopoly power, the freeing up of the market for vegetable seed, the relaxation of seed prices and the toleration of seed trade across political boundaries and intemationally. B. CONSTRAINTS 2.4 Policy, :regulatory, technical and financial factors present major inhibitions to the growth in the seed sector, as follows. Policy and Regulatory Constraints 2.5 The Secd Administration Regulations of May 1989 contain administrative policy guidelines forrmulated to strengthen the development of seed activities by insuring
 ..ppropriate seed quality standards and safeguarding the rights and interests of seed breeders, distributors and users in a centrally planned economy. The regulations contain policies on germplasm management, plant variety registration, strategic seed reserve management and quarantine. Government considers they are inadequate for supporting the new policy to develop a commercial seed sector. In particular, they do not deal with issues of domestic trade across political boundaries, truth in labeling, distribution, breeder rights, farmers rights, liability and compensation, and research institutions. 2.6 Plant Breeder Rights. At present, China has no legislation to protect intellectual property rights in plant cultivars. Without such protection, it is currently very difficult for breeders to sustain themselves financially in the current climate of diminishing government subsidies for new cultivar development. The 1992 patent law provides some measure of protection for hybrid seed. This law protects the breeding methods and techniques used to produce new cultivars, but not the cultivars thernselves. In the case of hybrid seed, users must return to the seed supplier for each growing season, and where the availability of parent lines is tightly controlled, the patentability of the breeding process affords protection to the cultivar. For open pollinated species such as wheat, however, it is generally not possible for the breeder to gain adequate financial remuneration after the initial release of seed, since farmers may produce seed for their own use without consideration of ownership. 2.7 The lack of plant cultivar protection has discouraged foreign breeders from introducing new germplasm from outside China. It is impossible to quantify the lost opportunity represented by lack of access to the latest germplasm, but it has been estimated by scientists ftom a multinational seed company that yields of strategically important crops such as corn could be increased by as much as 15 percent if new germplasm is introduced from outside China. 2.8 Seed Testing. The testing of seed for the physical attributes of germination, purity and moisture content is a pivotal procedure in the management of seed quality. MOA has acknowledged the requirement for seed testing within its regulatory framework through promulgation of national seed standards and the establishment of a national seed testing laboratory and associated laboratories at provincial and lower levels. In practice, however, most of the seed laboratories are inadequately equipped and staff poorly trained. The rules and procedures utilized by laboratories are outdated and do not reflect modem knowledge in the area of seed science. The Bank-assisted Agricultural Support Services Project (ASSP, Cr. 2462-CHA) (para. 2.31) is currently addressing some of these deficiencies, and the present project would do considerably more. 2.9 Since 1991, China has been a member of the International Seed Testing Association (ISTA), the primary international organization concerned with the development and promulgation of seed testing methods. China's membership has been through the Bureau of Animal Husbandry with the Forage Seed Laboratory of Beijing Agricultural University being the sole accredited member laboratory. The National Seed Testing Laboratory is currently not a member of ISTA.
 - 12 - 2.10 Seed Certification. Most countries have developed programs for the certification of the genetic integrity of plant cultivars within their seed regulatory framework. These programs associated with the production of seed, essentially maintain an evidentiary trail on the seed of cultivars as it is multiplied through successive generations. They are an assurance to seed users that the cultivar stated on a label is true to type. At present China does not have a reguilated seed certification scheme, as cultivar assurance has been the responsibility of government operated seed companies, and this process has operated satisfactorily. As the seed industry becomes more deregulated in the future, particularly if seed companies cease to be state-owned enterprises, it may be necessary to have a v oluntary seed certification scheme available in the public interest. However, this is not Seen as an immediate necessity. 2.11 Most, if not all seed exported from China at present is of vegetable species, for which seed certification is not required internationally. Should seed of other species, e.g., corn, be exported, China may need to conform to the OECD Seed Scheme for the certification of seed in international trade, since importing countries usually require internationally acceptable certification procedures. While possibly useful in the future, the development of seed certification programs for either internal or external markets is not seen as a current constraint on the development of the seed sector. 2.12 Crop V7ariety Examination, Evaluation, Approval and Registration. China has had a formal system for the examination, evaluation, release and registration of crop varieties for more than 30 years, now under the authority of Articles 12 and 13 of the 1989 Seed Regulations. All crop varieties developed in China or imported have to be examined, evaluated, approved and registered before the seeds or vegetative propagules can be multiplied and marketed to farmers. This system has the hierarchical structure of most institutionls in the agricultural sector: NCVEACO coordinates and supervises the examination and approval of new crop varieties at the national level with assistance of 14 professional crop-group subcommittees and the Provincial Crop Variety Evaluation and Approval Corrumittees have responsibility for the examination and approval of crop varieties at the provincial level also typically with the assistance of 14 provincial expert subcommittees. 2.13 Under this two-tier examination, evaluation and approval system, the application for release and approval of a new crop variety is usually made at the provincial level with testing/examination in provincial trials for one year before it is entered into national trials. A minimum of two years in provincial regional trials (PRT) for distinctness, uniformity and stability and two years in provincial field production trials (PFPT) for crop value and p:oductivity are generally required before a decision is made on provincial relea:e ind the same for national approval, i.e., two years national regional trials (NRT) and two years national field production trials (NFPT). Since the PFPT and the NRT ornmence after the first PRT, the time to approval and registration of new and/or imported crop varieties is three to four years at the provincial level and four to six years at the national level. Varieties approved and registered for national usage carry a GS prefix. Variety names are assigned by the NCVEACO.
 - 13 - 2.14 Although they are very formal and very conservative, the crop variety examination, evaluation and registration system and requirements have not been viewed as a significant constraint on either crop productivity or seed industry development until rather recently. The present view, however, is that with increasing emphasis on the adoption of advanced technologies to increase crop productivity coinciding with the commercialization of the seed industry, the present system will now be a significant impediment to increased agricultural productivity unless it is substantially reformed and liberalized. An example cited is an important and much needed IRRI rice variety that took four years for registration. Reforms especially needed include shortening of the period for approval and registration, relaxation of cropping area restrictions and permission for breeders to name varieties. Additionally, NCVEACO is ill-equipped to carry out its assigned role. Among other things, it needs: (a) a modem computerized information system to record, analyze and store the voluminous data on provincially and nationally registered varieties, so that crop variety catalogs and databases can be efficiently assembled, and (b) an adequate temperature- and humidity-controlled seed store to maintain samples of seeds under trial prior to their being stored in perpetuity with the National Institute of Germplasm Resources. 2.15 Prices and Trade. Until 1992, procurement and selling prices of improved seeds were decided by provincial seed corporations within a price range suggested by the provincial DOA and the provincial price bureau, which in turn was based on prices established for commodiity grains. In principle, the seed prices were set at 10-15 percent more than the prevailing free market grain price. Thus, seed prices did not reflect the costs actually involved in producing and marketing seeds. A second level of controls affecting seed prices comes from government limitation of the profits that state enterprises can make from seed operations. Since 1992, there has been considerable liberalization of seed prices. In many cases seed prices are now determined by the market. For instance, hybrid corn seed is usually now about three times the commercial corn price, and hybrid rice six times. However, in some provinces the prices of these seeds are still constrained to be only 10-15 percent above the commercial price. 2.16 Until recently trade was limited to within a seed company's jurisdiction, typically a county, but in the case of a provincial seed company, the province. Interprovincial and even inter-county trade was small and occurred mostly under specific government instructions. Official regulations also restricted trading and marketing of seed to seed companies. It llow appears that there are no longer any enforced controls on trade between provinces. 1Nevertheless, a number of restrictions remain, except in times of shortage: (a) only designated companies, invariably state or provincial companies, can distribute hybrid seeds for the rmain crops, (b) most provinces insist that seed produced in anc-her province is sold only through the importing province's provincial seed company, (c) interprovincial imports are frequently subject to a levy of up to 10 percent ad valorem, (d) there are a large number of permits required to establish a seed company, and (e) the present system of certification and seed control discourages competition. Freedom to enter or exit the market, or a sector of a market, is essential, if farmers are to be given
 - 14 - the choice of ivhere to purchase their seeds. This is being addressed under the new seed law (para. 2.22). 2.17 State-0)v ;aed Enterprises. A major constraint for the development of a comr.e_ciaii.cd seed sector is the fact that all seed producers are state owned enterprises (SOEs) with all the ramifications that this entails. SOEs typically receive their orders From the state system and, as government services, do not compete with each other. The seed companies are now in an ambiguous situation. On the one hand, they are expected to continue to play a social role by providing farmers with quality seed at set, minimum prices; on the other, they are now expected to become commercial. In general, they are still more concerned with the volume of output to meet state requirements than with profit generation and sustainable investment. As a further aspect of their status as SOEs, they remain obliged to provide housing, health, education and pension services for staffs that are usually much larger than actual labor need. Technical Cornstraints 2.18 There are two major technical constraints for the development of a modern commercialized seed industry. Once recognized, they can only be addressed by major investment. The first technical constraint is the lack of sufficiently developed seed production bases. Quality seed production has to be done in seed production bases to achieve proper isolation, uniform crop management and efficient operation. Unfortunately, because farms in China are small (averaging 0.1 ha/capita), organizing efficient production bases composed of individual farmers is difficult. Thus, seed companies desiring to enter the market for quality seed will typically plan to develop production bases on tracts that they manage. In this regard, state farms, with readily available plots, will have an advantage. In all cases, the development of quality production bases will require significant investment and upgraded production technology. 2.19 The lack of seed testing laboratoiies equipped with full-time seed testing personnel and seed testing equipment is another major technical constraint to improved seed quality. A shortage of modern, efficient processing equipment and facilities and a sLonage of manpower trained in modern seed production regulation and control procedures is a second major technical constraint to seed quality. Together these deficiencies make it very difficult for most seed companies to produce and market seed of good physical and genetic quality. The experience of companies that have been re- equipped with modem facilities demonstrates the benefits to be obtained from the use of efficient processing facilities (threshers, driers, cleaners, graders, delinters, chemical applicators, and packaging equipment etc.). A prerequisite for the modernization of the industry is therefore a major program of investment in new machinery and the related training of opeirating staff. Finarcial Constraints 2.20 Most seed enterprises appear to be affected by a shortage of working capital for the operation of production bases (i.e. annual purchase of inputs for supply to farmer-
 - 15- p.-oducers) and for the purchase of raw seed. An analysis of the typical cost structure of a provincial seed companay in 1994 indicates that during peak periods purchasing of raw seed represents some 80 percent of the capital requirements of a seed company. 2.21 Most enterprises also appear to find it difficult to raise adequate amounts of investment capital for the purchase of new equipment, especially for foreign exchange for imported machinery, and for the improvement of production bases (e.g., irrigation and drainage facilities, and access roads). At the most basic level, the firms' financial difficulties are a reflection of the limited ability they have to generate and retain surplus revenue over and above immediate financial needs. The margin between the sale price of processed seed and the procurement price paid to farmers is insufficient to cover processing costs in fill, let alone generate sufficient profit to finance reinvestment. Analysis of seed company proposals submitted for inclusion under this project indicated that only about one third were viable on the basis of 1994 selling prices. The long term viability of a commercial seed industry will depend on improved access to short and long termn capital, rationalization of the industry leading to fewer but more competitive enterprises, and fiL-'her liberalization of prices (para. 2.15) to allow adequate profit mar gin-. C. RECENT DEVELOPMENTS Poliky and Regulatory Framework 2.22 Seed Policy. China's overall seed policy aims to increase the use of improved agricuitLiral and horticultural seeds in order to increase the country's food and fiber production. Policks to promote seed-sector commercialization include shifting from an administrative hierarchy of seed companies (provincial, prefecture and county) to a competitive structure and to support efficient companies. 2.23 To achieve this goal the following seed sectoral objectives are under consideration by the government for the year 2000: (a) Law drafting. To prepare and enact "the Seed Law of China" and "New Plant Variety Protection Regulations" and detailed implementing particulars, including participation in the Intemational Union for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (UPOV) Convention; (b) Separation of the administrative and business functions of existing administrative seed companies. To create an independent official seed administration and monitoring system to regulate the seed industry and to promote the establishment of modem seed corporations; (z) Replacement of cereal varieties. To replace present varieties of main cereals such as rice, wheat and corn with new varieties to firther increase yield by 10 percent;
 - 16 - (d) Increase in the business volume of state-owned companies. To increase the business volume of state-owned companies from 3.5 mil tons to 5.0 mil tons; and (e) Improvement in seed quality. To achieve at least the usage of national class 2 seeds in all field crops. 2.24 Seed Legislation. Certain areas of seed law are to be amplified and strengthened, while other aspects of the seed sector are to be deregulated. The overall effect will be to facilitate comrnercial trade on the one hand and tighten official control of seed quality on the other. The changes proposed by Government would have the effect of: (a) Simplifying the procedures for examination and approval of varieties for cultivation and use and upgrading of the registration system; (b) Providing for intellectual property protection for plant cultivars; (c) Strengthening official inspection as a quality monitoring tool of the government to ensure user protection; (d) Ending the current seed production monopoly and strengthening of seed production contract between seed companies and farmers; and (z) Strengthening the requirement of marketers to label and package seeds in accordance with prescribed standards. 2.25 Crop 'Variety Examination, Evaluation, Approval and Registration. Reforms under consideration would aim at: (a) speeding up procedures at the provincial level with automatic registration of provincially approved varieties in the National Registry; (b) reducing t!.e minimum time required for the introduction of new varieties of strategic crops to two years; (c) eliminating any distinction in terms of procedures or requirements for domestic or imported varieties; (d) reducing the time required for most vegetable crops, omamentals and other nonstrategic crops to a maximum of one year for observation trials; and (e) permitting breeders of new varieties to name them. 2.26 Plant Breeder Rights. In September 1994, a series of seminars were organized in China in ccnjunction with the International Union for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants (UPOV) to discuss the legislative framework of intellectual property protection for plants in the international context. In April 1995, a committee with members from MOA, the Miinistry of Forestry and the Patent Bureau began drafting legislation for plant breeder rights protection. The text of an initial draft was reviewed by an official from UPOV in October 1995 to ensure conformity with the 1978 Act. 2.27 Seed Testing. The former National Seed Administration Station completed a translation of the latest International Seed Testing Association (ISTA) rules and procedures into (Chinese in 1994 as a prelude to strengthening seed quality testing.
 - 17 - Manuals containing these rules and procedures were printed in early 1995 and officially released on August 18, 1995 and will be widely distributed to seed companies and official seee quality control laboratories. The NATESC laboratory is anticipating the completion of new laboratory facilities in 1996 under the ASSP, after which time it will be in a position to join ISTA. 2.28 Seed Production. 'The Government plans to extend seed production authorization to allow production outside the breeding location, to allow foreign seed companies to produce in China and to allow for contract seed multiplication for re-export. In times of high seed denrand, contracts for seed production have often been broken by farmers, causing trade problems for seed companies. The new seed law would attempt to address this issue. 2.29 Seed Marketing. Currently, only seed companies are allowed to market seed (except for farmer-to-farmer trade which is allowed). The Government proposes revision that would allow any appropriately qualified body to market seed. A license will still be required. The requirements for labeling and packaging of seed will be strengthened with greater adherence to truthful labeling principles. Consumer information on labels would be required. These provisions are directed at increasing the responsibility of the seed marketing sector for product quality. D. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREvIOus BANK GROUP PROJECTS 2.30 The Seeds Project (Cr. 1577-CHA), which was completed in 1990, provided modern seed processing equipment and trained staff in sced processing, testing and certification at 18 seed centers. The project was successful in establishing modem processing facilities and expanding the capacity of some 80 seed production bases. The project was less successful in introducing modern methods of seed quality assurance and control procedures. The Project Management Office (PMO) established under the project to supervise project implementation across 12 provinces and 2 autonomous regions was very effective. The most important lessons were in the area of marketing and pricing as follows: (a) Greater attention should have been given to estimating market demand for the project's seed output. Estimates for conventional, self-pollinated grain and oil seeds were too optimistic, resulting in substantial quantities of unsold seed, which were disposed of as grain or feed. The shortfall in demand occurred in part because, with increased freedom of action, farmers used more of their own rather than purchased seed, and additionally because of shifts in cropping patterns away from grain and oil seed crops. (b) The project should have provided for adequate processing margins based on a full analysis of costs. The controlled seed prices anticipated by the project were set at levels that in actual operation did not allow seed companies to cover costs. Production of quality seed, made possible by the superior equipment provided under the project, required among other things, a costly
 - 18- 5-15 percent seed reject rate. Controlled prices for quality seed needed to be set higher; or prices should have been liberalized. 2.31 The Agricultural Support Services Project (ASSP-Cr. 2462-CHA), which became effective in 1993, assists in upgrading the facilities of 10 provincial, 14 prefecture and 41 county seed companies, in strengthening the plant quarantine system ani in establishing a seed quality control system that is independent of seed companies. It is significant that t.e Ministry of Agriculture's (MOA) current policy is that in the future all provinces will be expected to establish external quality control systems that are independent of szed companies. It also contains a small pilot program of cor1;mercialization of three seed companies. A recent review of these model seed companies revealed that they have become financially independent entities (although the ownership of capital assets has yet to be resolved within the framework of State owned enterprises) and have restructured their operations to take advantage of commercial opportunities. The companies are doing very well. In all three cases, the Government has provided budgetary financing for the seed quality control agencies. 2.32 Under the government policy at the time the ASSP was initiated, both seed company management and regulation operated within a strict hierarchical structure with the national agencies determining policy and the provinces conducting operations. The system clearly did not allow for independent monitoring of the quality of the seed reaching the market and therefore was an unsatisfactory procedure. Under the ASSP, the Government agreed to institute policies requiring the separation of official seed quality control from the commercial activities of the seed companies by transferring staff and budget from the seed company structure to government regulatory agencies at provincial, prefectural and county level in the target provinces. Financing was made available through the Project to equip these regulatory agencies with vehicles and laboratory equipment to operate an efficient and effective monitoring system. 2.33 Full implementation of the ASSP has not yet been completed and a recent review revealed certain lessons learned in the management and implementation of the project that will need to be applied in the proposed project as follows: (a) training delay can affect project progress; and (b) delay in procurement of laboratory equipment can severely curtail quality control activities and delay the separation of quality control from production. 2.34 The Henan ADP (Cr. 2242-CHA), which became effective in August 23, 1991, supported the construction of 20 seed processing centers to produce, process and market good quality wheat, rice, corn and soybean seeds to meet existing and additional demand in the project area. The centers are now in operation. Lessons learned from this project have been used in designing this project, as follows: (a) the processing plants should be close to the production base; (b) for efficient operation and convenient relocation, the processing plants should be prefabricated; (c) the quality of seed stores is important in keeping seeds in good condition; (d) adequate equipment technical specifications are essential (to ensure that the equipment will incorporate new technology and that a service
 -19- contract, a supply of spare parts, installation and training of operators are included in the bid package); and (e) processing lines should be procured as a single procurement package from a single supplier to ensure that the responsibility for satisfactory operation remains with o-.e company. 2.35 The Seed Development Project (SDP) (Ln. 3891-UA) in Ukraine, effective in 1995, also incorporates some relevant lessons learned in other Bank Group projects in, among others, Indonesia, India and Pakistan. It aims to improve agricultural productivity through increasing the supply of high-quality seeds for corn, sugar beets and sunflowers. It would support the development of private seed production enterprises, improve the regulatory framework and support germplasm maintenance and improvement. Lessons reflected in this project are: (a) the ability of seed companies to operate independently is crucial to private seed sector development; (b) price and trade liberalization are essential to plomote seed trade and international cooperation; (c) technical assistance is required for introdu_ing new management systems and preparing operating plans; (d) maintenance and improvement of germplasm benefit from a research and development program and from income generation from licensing of new varieties. These lessons have been taken into consideration while preparing the proposed project. E. RATIONALE FOR BANK GROUP INVOLVEMENT 2.36 The Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) presented to the Board in June 1995 commits the Bank Group to assisting China to implement market-oriented reforms, particularly the reform and restructuring of state enterprises. The proposed project would support that strategy and enterprise restructuring by transferring technical and managerial know-how to seed enterprises, which would also benefit from increased managerial and fmancial autonomy. Involvement of the Bank Group in the project would, in addition, allow it to contribute its experience to key aspects of the modemization and commercialization- of the seed sector. Its experience in technology transfer would be a particularly valuable contribution in the areas of advanced seed varieties, new seed development techniques, good research management, efficient seed certification, modem processing technology, effective quality control and appropriate effluent treatment. The Bank Group's experience in commercialization in many countries in the areas of enterprise govemance, market liberalization, private sector development, regulatory development, reform sequencing, legal restructuring, financial development, and efficient business practice would assist in the implementation of the project. Indeed, project preparation itself has already assisted project staff and policy-makers in leaming about development of commercial seed industries of other countries through seminars and a study tour. It also facilitated the opening of links with multinational seed enterprises, which may lead to possible joint ventures. F. DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS 2.37 Modernization of the seed sector and the development of a commercial focus will be ineffective without policy reform at all levels of government. The central government
 - 20 - is committecl to developing a modem seed sector and has already begun to introduce a number of policy reforms with respect to the liberalization of seed prices and the separation of quality control from seed production. These are encouraging developments, which began with the implementation of the ASSP, and need to be further developed and consolidated. This proposed project would provide support for the separation of seed quality management systems in four provinces (Guizhou, Shandong, Shanxi and Zhejiang) not supported under the ASSP. This is essential if seed quality control is to be improved in China. The project in addition would support a number of other policy reformrs, in particular the liberalization of trade, the revision of the seed laws, the development and implementation of plant breeders rights protection, the use of modem ii'ternational standards for seed testing, the revision of the crop varietal evaluation and registration system, and the development of a voluntary system of seed certification for use in iaitemational trade in seed. All of these developments are under active review by the authorities in China. 2.3R China s seed sector is in a transitional stage. As described in para. 2.17, seed compariaes are still state owned enterprises (SOEs). The government is seriously discussing overall state enterprise reform and such general reforms will affect seed enterprises. State-owned seed enterprises are also subject to their own regime of controls and guidance. Seed pricing and trade are still not fully liberalized for certain strategic crops, and only vegetable and horticulture seeds are fully liberalized. Under these circumstances, profitable seed enterprises have been able to develop a mix of activities, augmenting production of less profitable conventional grain seeds with production of more profitable hybrid grain seeds and those sold in liberalized vegetable and horticulture markets. Since it is likely that the seed sector will still not be fully liberalized within the next three years, the overall rationale for the project is therefore the development of the foundations of a commercial seed industry by modernizing those forward looking seed enterprises that could subsequently become the leading companies in a national seed industry, after SOE reforms and fuller liberalization of prices and trade in the seed industry have taken effect. 2.39 Stated in other terms, the project aims to commercialize the seed sector, not necessarily to privatize it. Commercialization under the project would increase efficiency by improving management and creating incentives for seed enterprises to behave like seed enterprises in other countries. All companies would be required to provide an opening balance sheet with all items, including transferred equity valued according to the 1993 accounting standards. 2.40 The project would not directly address the social responsibilities of the seed companies. Project companies would not provide housing, but rather compensate workers with. higher salaries. Companies would provide for pensions and health insurance rather than direct provision. 2.41 Seed enterprises will evolve within the framework of a facilitative national seed sector policy. But without a program of support to evolving firms, this evolution could
 - 21 - be too slow to generate an efficient seed industry in a reasonable time frame or even to sustain the momentum of commercialization. What is needed is a nucleus group of active, technolugically adept, competitive seed companies. At preparation, almost 100 seed enterprises were interested in joining the project. Bank Group missions established technical, financial and business criteria to evaluate their proposed investments, business and marketing plans and selected 31 seed enterprises and one seed machinery firm. These seed enterprises are located in Fujian, Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Shandong, Shanxi, Sichuan and Zhejiang. The seed machinery firm is located in Shanghai. The selection criteria were as follows: (a) Technical: The proposals for the production, processing, storage and marketing of seeds are technically feasible. Production would meet national quality specifications (or international specifications where exports were proposed). (b) Business Risk: The proposal adequately addresses the commercial and business risks associated with creating or expanding production, processing and marketing operations. The enterprise would have more than one product line and would not be reliant on untried or new products or processes. (c) Funding Adequacy: The firn would provide at least 20 percent of their oNvn equity and would have government guarantees for the repayment of the project loan, counterpart funding and loans for working capital. (d) Investment Analysis: The investment and production plan would produce sufficient financial rate of return to support the loan repayments, interest on the loans, and dividends to shareholders, in addition to providing funds for investnent in long tern growth, even at 80 percent production capacity or with variation of 10 percent in production costs and selling prices. Assurances werc obtained that subloans would be made for subprojects that are determined, on the basis of guidelines acceptable to the Bank Group, to be technically feasible and economically, financially and commercially viable. 2.42 In addition, eligibility criteria were established for provinces to be included in the project so as to ensure successful implementation of the project at the provincial level. These criteria were agreed during negotiations as follows: (a) Separation of extemal quality control from the seed companies, and the provincial government guarantee of budgetary support for the external quality control agencies after its separation (para. 3.7). (b) Acceptance of at least one seed company for inclusion in the project. (c) Execution of project implementation agreements (PIAs) with MOF and MOA (para. 4.5).
 - 22 - 3. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.1 The main objective of the project is to assist the Government in developing a viable commercial seed sector, which can not only produce high quality seeds in sufficient quantity and variety to satisfy farmer needs but also operates through efficient, self-sustained commercial enterprises. 3.2 The project would assist in the commercialization of the seed sector by: (a) helping the Government establish a seed policy and a regulatory framework that would enhance the competitiveness of the seed sector and encourage international cooperation, (b) supporting the modernization and rationalization of selected seed companies, and (c) assisting in strengthening institutions so they can provide effective service and technical support to the seed sector. B. PROJECT COMPONENTS 3.3 The project would have three major components as follows: (a) Policy and Regulatory Framework; (b) Commercialization of Selected Seed Companies; and (c) Institutional Strengthening. C. DETAILED FEATURES Policy and Regulatory Framework 3.4 This component is designed to: (a) Assist the Governmenit with assessment and, where needed, strengthening of seed laws, regulations and administrative instructions in respect of the official examination and approval of cultivars for use, authorization for seed production and commercialization activities, labeling and packaging standards and strengthening of seed inspection and quarantine provisions; and (b) Assist the development and implementation of a suitable legal framnework for protection of plant breeders rights legislation and the Government's accession to the UPOV convention on intellectual property protection for plants.
 - 23 - 3.5 MOA is in the initial phase of strengthening national seed legislation and operating regulations and implementation protocols. The general thrust of new legislation has been developed and the areas to be strengthened have been identified. It is important for the effective operation of the project, which aims to facilitate commercialization of the seed sector, that this process be expedited and that the new legislation is both comprehensive and facilitative of international trade in seeds. The project would provide a few person-months of technical assistance to assist the seed law drafting committee in reviewing technical parameters and the draft seed laws. A study tour would be provided for four persons for two weeks during the early part of project implementation, to study application of seed laws and seed labeling as a quality control mechanism in seed marketing. 3.6 The government intends to develop and implement a legal framework for the protection of intellectual property rights for plant varieties. This legal protection is vitally important for the acquisition of new varieties by seed companies and would buttress the commercial viability of the seed marketing sector. In addition to providing for plant variety protection within the country, the Government has indicated its desire to accede to the 1978 Act of the UPOV Convention to facilitate international trade and access to improved germplasm of crop species from abroad. The legal framework will therefore need to be compatible with the provisions of the 1978 Act of UPOV as well as having the appropriate operatioiial mechanisms for its effective operation in China. The prcject would provide for an international legal expert, preferably from UPOV, to assist the technical group in China to finalize the proposed framework. It would also provide an additional study tour for four persons for two weeks to study application of plant breeders' right registrations. 3.7 The Government's policy is to separate internal seed quality management by seed companies from official seed quality control by regulatory agencies (para. 2.32). In 1995, separation was carried out in eight provinces under the ASSP; namely Liaoning, Shanghai, Hunan, Sichuan, Guangxi, Jiangsu and Shaanxi. The other ASSP provinces, Heilongjiang and Hebei, are expected to achieve separation by the end of 1996 upon completion of office and laboratory buildings and the procurement of laboratory equipment, providing remaining budget problems are solved. Since a complete separation is essential to further reform under this project, a condition of eligibility to participate in the project would be that the provinces have completed the above- mentioned separation and established a suitable, financially sustainable system of seed quality control. Commercialization of Selected Seed Companies 3.8 The main objective of this component would be to prepare a core group of about 31 active, technically adept and competitive seed companies as a foundation for a viable commercial seed sector-15 seed companies and 16 state farm companies. These enterprises would introduce new genetic materials, improve seed quality and strengthen their institutional, marketing and sales networks by forming liaisons with Chinese and
 - 24 - foreign institutions, suppliers and marketing agencies. The project would encourage joint venture agreements with foreign suppliers to upgrade the seed processing equipment and technology of the companies. A detailed description of the selected companies and a summarv of their business plans can be found in Annex 1. 3.9 These companies would, upon completion of agreed eligibility requirements for participation in the project, receive subloans from their respective provinces to carry out the following activities: (a) Improve Company Seed Production Bases. In order to develop their production bases, a number of the seed companies need investment in land development, irrigation facilities, drainage, power supply and rural roads. The project would also finance farm machinery and equipment such as tractors, trailers and seed drills. (b) Improved Variety of Seed. The project would assist about half of the companies in improving their seed stock by producing or purchasing new genetic materials or improved varieties of seed. The project would finance the purchase of domestic and international license agreements for new varieties, new parent lines from research institutes for multiplication, construction of greenhouses, development of mother-tree gardens, and equipment for dissue culture laboratories. It would also finance a small quantity of production inputs such as fertilizer and pesticides. (c) Improve Storage and Processing Facilities. Incremental production under the project would need to have proper storage facilities and improved processing technologies in order to increase the quality of the seeds. A number of companies proposed to enlarge their storage areas. A few companies proposed cold storage facilities and seed silos. Most of the companies requested finance for construction of processing facilities, including processing equipment, drying floors and buildings to house processing equipment, power and boiler equipment and seed storage areas. The processing line equipment would include intake conveyors, intake storage bins, driers, cleaners, graders, sorters, coating machines, weighers, packing machines, associated switchgear and control panels. The equipment would be supplied as integrated processing lines, the design of which would depend on the seeds to be processed. Capacities would be either 1.5 t/hr, 3 t/hr or 5 t/hr. Some cotton seed producers require acid delinting machinery. The investment would also include design and commissioning costs, spare parts and chemicals for seed treatment. Two person months of technical assistance would be required to assist in preparing technical specifications and bidding documents for these processing equipment. (d) Internal Quality Control. The project would finance construction of small laboratories and supply them with equipment for quality control according
 - 25 - to International Seed Testing Authority standards. Depending on the size of the company, the labs would be equipped and staffed to handle between 2,000 to 5,000 samples per year. Staff would be trained in modem inspection procedures. (e) Company Management. The project would provide technical assistance to each company in the area of management. Several companies are in the process of consolidation and are changing the structure of their management. The project would provide technical assistance and training in the following management areas: management of the enterprise, financial control, seed handling technology, and plant operation and maintenance. Joint ventures with foreign companies would be encouraged under the project as a means to improve company management. The project would finance refurbishment of office buildings and provide vehicles, computers, office equipment and training equipment. (f) Marketing and Pricing. The project emphasizes effective marketing. Thus, the project would provide training to managers and staff in market analysis, sales strategies and effective pricing. The project would encourage the establishment of sales networks and alliances with other companies in other provinces and countries and help seed companies develop the capacity to gather market intelligence and collect and analyze data. The project would finance construction of sales offices, office equipment, showrooms, storage rooms and retail stores. To improve distribution of seed, the project would finance the procurement of trucks and other vehicles. (g) Initial Seed Stock. Seed stock is a major part of the materials requirement tor the seed companies. Seed companies generally purchase seeds after harvesting, and process and store them for six months or more until the subsequent year's planting season. Lack of operating funds has been a major constraint limiting quantities purchased and processed. Under this project, there would be a need for $57.4 million to nurchase the initial stock of seed. The project would finance 50 percent of the stock purchased. The rest would be financed by commercial banks. Insofar as the seed stocks embody improved genetics, the investment in such stocks constitutes an investment in advanced technology. (h) Seed Machinery. The project would support the modernization of Shanghai Xiangmin Machinery Company, which manufactures a wide range of agricultural machinery and seed processing equipment. The company is well recognized as providing good seed processing equipment, including 20 sets for the Henan ADP financed by IDA (para. 2.34). The company lacks good designs for key equipment such as air screen separators and gravity tables. It also needs high quality machine tools, screen presses and perforators to produce accurate drum separators and screens. The company
 - 26 - does not have computer aided design (CAD) facilities, which are now used by most foreign suppliers to produce plant layout drawings to each client's requirements, or computer aided manufacturing (CAM) equipment, which translates CAD designs into shop floor manufacturing instructions. The project would finance the construction of a new workshop, necessary machine tools and CAD/CAM design and manufacturing equipment. To upgrade their processing equipment technology, the best approach would be a joint venture with a seed equipment manufacturer. Should such a joint venture be established, the project would finance a contract for technology transfer on a direct-contract basis. 3.10 The total base cost of the investment in this component is estimated at Y 1,390 million. Institutional Strengthening 3.11 The project would strengthen government institutions which provide services to the seed sector as follows: (a) Variety examination, release and protection: (i) National Crop Variety Examination and Approval Committee Office (NCVEACO). The objective is to develop the present NCVEACO into a variety release and protection office. The two subcomponents to be established and developed are computerization of variety information and establishment of a plant variety protection implementation unit. NCVEACO would be provided with additional staff. The project would provide a computer system and computer training, other training, study tours and workshops on the protection of new plant varieties, and a small prefabricated cold store. The investrnent cost is estimated at Y 1.4 million. (ii) Provincial Crop Variety Examination and Approval Offices. Similar interventions are planned for the four project seed administration stations in four provinces. The cost is included in the investment cost of the individual seed management stations. (b) Seed quality control and seed certification: (i) National Seed Testing Center (NSTC). NSTC of the National Agricultural Technical Extension Center would be equipped and its staff trained to initiate pilot work on management and certification of fruit tree seedlings and ornamental plants for later introduction throughout China. The investment cost would be Y 2.0 million.
 - 27 - (ii) Provincial Seed Administration Stations. The project aims to ensure the existence in the project provinces of an official independent seed regulation and control system, including a working "truth in labeling" mechanism and a voluntary seed certification system. Most project provinces already have independent quality control agencies, with assistance from the ASSP. The project would support the establishment of such independent quality control agencies in Guizhou, Shandong, Zhejiang and Shanxi Provinces, which did not benefit from the ASSP in thls regard. For these provinces, the project would support seed laboratory and office construction, seed testing equipment, greenhouses, vehicles and computers, and local and foreign training on field inspection, laboratory testing and cross-check testing. The total investment cost in the four provinces would be Y 36.1 million. 3.12 Strengthening of the Central Project Management Office (CPMO). The CPMO would raise part of its operating funds through management fees charged to the seed companies. The project would support project management by providing office equipment, training and study tours. It would also provide operating funds (not Bank- financed) and training to carry out the supervision, monitoring and evaluation required under the project. Informal Seed Sector 3.13 It is claimed that about 20-25 percent of the self-pollinating, conventional seeds needed in China are obtained from seed companies/stations, while the rest are seeds saved by farmers for planting the next crop. If this estimate of the rate of seed replacement is correct, it is higher in China than in other countries in the region with well developed crop agriculture. While the rate of seed replacement for self-pollinated crops in China appears to be at a level judged to be satisfactory by Chinese farmers and many professional agronomists (seed prices are quite low and there do not appear to be any general and chronic supply shortages), a government decision has been made to increase the seed replacement rate gradually to about 40 percent through organized seed promotion campaigns. In fact, there is no substantial and consistent evidence in other countries or in China that conventional self-pollinating crop replacement seeds from local seed companies are significantly more productive than seeds of the same variety saved on-farm for planting and therefore no evidence that there would be substantial economic gains from the considerable effort that would be involved in these campaigns. 3.14 The project would finance relatively simple surveys and studies to provide good data on the relative performance of farmer saved and company-supplied seeds, which could be used by the seed companies in marketing and for guidance on the type and degree of involvement in production/marketing of self-pollinating seeds. The surveys/ studies would be done for two years for relatively modest costs by selected provincial seed management administrations for conventional rice and soybeans in Shandong and
 - 28 - wheat in Henan. An appropriate model for the surveys/studies would be the so-called planter box seed surveys, i.e., samples collected from farmers as they are planting their crop.
