The cost of six such surveys of three crops is estimated to be about Y 65,000. Details can be found in Annex 2. 3.15 Pilot Program. The objective of the pilot program is to give more intense attention to three companies receive subloans under the commercialization component of the project and provide them with training and technical assistance to ensure successful implementation of activities promoted under the project. The preparation team has already given special assistance to the three pilot companies by reviewing their proposed internal management structure and their business and marketing plans. The companies are required to provide an opening balance sheet with all items, including transferred equity, valued according to generally accepted accounting principles (para. 2.39). They would minimize expenditures on social services, substituting higher wages and salaries for such things as free housing for permanent employees and hiring temporary workers in the peak season rather than permanent staff. They would also provide insurance plans for pensions and health coverage, rather than providing these items directly. They would have effective quality assurance systems, which would not only test seeds but also ensure the production of high quality seed. Benchmarks have been established for the three pilot companies and would be closely monitored during supervision. At the mid-term review, progress would be evaluated and the experience gained from the pilot program shared with the other project seed companies. Description of the pilot program can be found in Annex 3. 3.16 The three pilot companies are being developed from (a) a state farm seed company, CD) a prefecture seed company, and (c) a provincial seed company. The proposed operations of these companies will represent three different company structures, all of which could be adopted by other entities pursuing the objective of commercialization. 3. 1 7 The state farm model is based on Zhangqiu Leek Seed Company (ZLSC), a seed business that is io be spun off from the state farm and establish itself as a limited liability company. The company would have a Board of Directors to give guidance on all major operating and financial issues. This company would have a licensing agreement with ZhLtngqiu Municipal Leek Research Institute (ZMLRI), the only institute in China which has de,-doped new varieties of leek. ZLSC would be responsible for the production and marketing of foundation and commercial seed. The general manager of the company would have autonomy for company management. He would be assisted by two deputies, one being responsible for finance and marketing, the other responsible for seed production and conditioning. The company would establish an internal quality control system reporting directly to the management of the general manager. 3.18 The company would arrange with ZMLRI to be supplied with new, improved germplasm on a regular basis. ZMLRI would have the responsibility of describing these varieties and obtaining protection under plant breeder rights regulations. ZLSC would have the responsibility of ensuring varietal purity so that the marketed product truly
 - 29- reflects the characteristics described by ZMLRI. ZLSC would pay a license fee (royalty) to ZMLRI for the right to produce and market the products developed by the institute, and this license would be established as a percentage of the price at which ZLSC sells its seed. This arrangement would significantly change the marketing of seeds; ZLSC would regularly launch new products into the market and it would have to manage "product cycles" including the phasing out of products on the decline. 3.19 ZiBo Prefecture Seed Compoany (ZPSC), a prefecture company model, would operate as a limited liability company. ZPSC would have a Board of Directors to monitor and guide the actions of management. The company intends to continue operating as a stand-alone operation but to increase its market share in hybrid com and to expand interregional marketing of vegetable seeds. It has an in-house research program for Chinese cabbage and recently acquired the production and marketing rights to a corn hybrid. 3.20 In vegetable seeds, ZPSC has about 1,400 accessions of Chinese cabbage as its proprietary germplasm pool, and its research effort is directed towards the development of hybrid.;. While the company considers its genetic basis sufficient and its hybrids superior as regards quality and earliness, ZPSC would change its products release policy to regularly launch new products, as described above for Zhangqiu, and also seek protection of new varieties under PBR. ZPSC would begin significant efforts to identify other sources of improved germplasm nationally and intemationally (for Chinese cabbage, com and other crops). These products would be secured for the company either through licensing or otherwise. The company currently has production and marketing rights for a hybrid com developed by Shandong Agricultural Research Institute. 3.21 ZPSC has already established proprietary packaging for "ZiBo Cabbage Seed," which clearly distinguishes it from any other source; this package also has created a brand image for the company in the interregional market. The company would accomplish its sales objectives by building on and expanding this brand identity. ZPSC currently sells its corn seeds within the prefecture; the company recently concluded contractual arrangements with 6 county seed companies to sell ZPSC corn seeds exclusively. ZPSC would also pursue sales opportunities outside the prefecture, most likely through some of its vegetable seed dealers. The company expects this strategy to be successful and projects an increase in sales of corn seeds from 500 tons to 5,000 tons annually. 3.22 Guangxi Provincial Seed Company (GPSC), a provincial seed company model, decided to convert to a limited liability stock company whose shareholders would be five county seed companies in addition to the province. The management of the company would be supervised by a board of directors elected by the shareholders. The company would be managed by a general manager who would not be a member of the board; this general manager would be assisted by three deputies. One deputy general manager would be responsible for seed production and conditioning, one for sales and marketing, and one for finance and administration. The departments of quality assurance and new product evaluation will report directly to the general manager. The company would operate from
 - 30 - its central location in Nanning where it also maintains its foundation seed farm; away from this center there will be five seed production locations and one sales office near the Viet Nam border. They would produce hybrid rice, hybrid corn, peanuts and kenaf seeds. 3.23 The shareholders would contribute to the company the right to use certain facilities for the production of seeds; five seed conditioning lines would be installed at these facilities. The shareholders would also make available to GPSC certain personnel during the harvest and conditioning season to allow the company to manage its seed crop and to keep its permanent staff at a minimum. GPSC would have, through its own staff, supervisory responsibility for operating and maintaining all seed production operations. The number of shares held by each shareholder would be determined based on the value of their contributions. 3.24 The clepartment for the evaluation of new varieties will perform a critical function, as none of the companies forming GPSC has any proprietary products or research programs or holds any licenses to such products. GPSC therefore must urgently obtain new varieties for testing from both national and international sources and evaluate them at multiple locations throughout the province and in the interregional markets. GPSC has been put in contact with potential international sources for new varieties and the implementation of an accelerated testing program for such new products will be one benchmark b) which this company will be evaluated. D. STATUS OF PREPARATION 3.25 The Crovernment is seriously committed to the policy and regulatory reforms. Several activities have been initiated and have estimated dates for completion. However, the speed of change will depend on the economic and political situation of the country. The government has concurred on the need for technical assistance, as provided for in the project (draft TORs in Annex 8). Detailed government institutional strengthening has been developed by the concerned institutions. 3.26 The preparation for commercializing seed companies is well-advanced. All participating seed enterprises have submitted feasibility reports, containing data on their seed production, processing, storage and marketing plans. Most enterprises have also provided preliminary designs and specifications for their administrative buildings, trading and retail cenlers, storage buildings and processing plants. 3.27 Detailed investment schedules have been prepared, together with production and operating cost schedules, cash flow statements, working capital computations, and financing plans. Local government guarantees have been secured by the participating seed enterprises for repayment of their Bank Group-financed subloans and for provision of counterp3: funds and working capital. Each enterprise has presented audited annual accounts to show that they have 20 percent equity available for investment in their project component. All of these documents are satisfactory.
 - 31 - E. IMPLEMENTATION SCHEDULE 3.28 The proposed project would be implemented over a five-year period, starting from 1996 through 2001. Investment in land development, civil works and buildings would start in year one, while niachinery and equipment delivery and installation would start in year two. In preparation for project implementation, training for personnel of the seed enterprises and the PMOs would be in the first two years. The seed enterprises are projected to start incremental production in year three or year four. This scheduling is considered reasenable, given that almost all the seed enterprises are already involved in seed processing and have experienced staff. Seed company's key activities schedules can be seen in Figure 2. F. COST ESTIMATES 3.29 The total project cost, including physical and price contingencies, is estimated at Y 1,824 million or $185.5 million at the existing initial exchange rate of Y 8.4 to $1. The foreign exchange component is estimated at $63.8 million or 34 percent of total project cost. The base cost estimates are computed from unit prices prevailing at the time of appraisal in October 1995. The total costs include value added taxes and import duties of $26.5 million or 14 percent of total project costs. Physical contingencies are estimated at 15 percent for equipment, 10 percent for materials and vehicles, 5 percent for civil works and zero for seed stocks, working capital, technical assistance, training, management cost and labor. Price contingencies are based on annual international price escalation rates for all goods and services when expressed in US dollars of 3.3 percent in 1996, 2.3 percent in 1997 and 2.5 percent from 1998 to 2001. Total contingencies over the five-year period amount to 8 percent of base costs in US dollars. When expressed in Yuan, annual price escalation rates of 17.5 percent were used for 1996 and 8.5 percent, 7.0 percent, 6.5 percent, 6.2 percent and 6.2 percent for 1997-2001. Total contingencies amount to 26 percent of base costs expressed in Yuan.

G. FINANCING 3.30 Bank Group financing would be an IDA credit of SDR 13.8 million ($20 million equivalent) and an IBRD Loan of $80 million. This would cover 54 percent of total project cost. The remaining 46 percent would be financed by national and provincial governments, commercial banks and self-raised funds. The contributions from each source are as follows: $ Million (a) IDA Credit 20.0 (b) IBRD Loan 80.0 (c) Central and Provincial Governments 4.0 (d) Commercial Banks 28.7 (e) Enterprise Self-raised funds 52.8 Total Financn 18 5u~
 - 33 - H. PROCUREMENT 3.31 All procurement of works and goods would be carried out in accordance with the Bank CGroup's guidelines for procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits, January 1995 and revised in January 1996, and all procurement would use China model bidding documents, prepared in consultation with the Bank Group, and based on the Bank Group's standard bidding documents for ICB. Procurement arrangements are detailed in Annex 4, Table 5 and summarized in Table 3.2 on the following page. 3.32 Works. Project works consisting of civil works and buildings valued at $31.4 million, are widely dispersed in 14 provinces and would be difficult to consolidate into larger packages. All of them are relatively small, the largest being less than $2.0 million, and would therefore, not be of interest to foreign contractors. Approximately 81 percent of works ($25.4 million) would be procured on the basis of National Competitive Bidding (NCB) procedures acceptable to the Bank Group. All buildings, valued at $22.2 million, would be procured on the basis of NCB. Building construction contracts would cover the supply of construction materials and the construction work at each project site. Of the civil works ($9.2 million), including land development and earth works for access road and irrigation ditches, only 35 percent ($3.2 million) can be packaged for NCB procurement. The remaining civil works valued at $6 million are small and widely scattered throughout the project and will not be of interest to contractors. They would therefore be undertaken through force account managed by county engineers in coordination with the seed companies. 3.33 Goods. To an extent practicable, contracts for goods shall be grouped in bid packages estimated to cost $200,000 equivalent or more each. Project goods consisting of machinery, equipment, vehicles and materials are estimated at $61.1 million. ICB procedures would be used for seed processing equipment ($26.2 million), truck and utility vehicles ($4.5 million) and fertilizer ($11.0 million), valued at $41.7 million or 68 percent of all goods. Domestic manufacturers would be allowed a margin of preference on ICB equal to 15 percent of the c.i.f. price of imported goods or the prevailing custom duty, whichever is lower. 3.34 Small office and electrical equipment ($2.2 million), farm machinery and implements ($0.8 million), and other equipment ($0.7 million) would be dispersed in location, spread over the project period and subject to continuing after-sale service requirements to the extent that none of them can be grouped in packages of more than $200,000 and would therefore be unlikely to be of interest to foreign suppliers without a significant local presence. They would, therefore, normally be procured under contracts awarded on the basis of NCB procedures acceptable to the Bank Group.

DISBURSEMENTS 3.,0 Disbursement for equipment, machinery, vehicles, licenses and materials would be n.Tade at 100 percent of foreign expenuitures for direct imports, 100 percent of the local, ex-factoiy cost for locally manufactured items, and 75 percent of expenditures for other items procured locally. Disbursement against civil works would be 50 percent of expenditures. Disbursement for seed stock wouid be 50 percent of the seed purchase. Disbursement For training, study tours and consultant services would be at 100 percent of expenditures. 3.41 Disbursements would be made against statements of expenditure in the case of overseas training, study tours, and contracts for goods and works costing less than $200,000 and consultant contracts costing less than $100,000 for firms and $50,000 for individual. A condition of disbursement for the seed stock for each subproject would be that operation plans for the subproject acceptable to the Bank Group have been prepared and the subproject's seed processing lines have been installed and are ready for operation. Disbursements for all works carried out under force account would be made against statements of physical progress achieved at each site at unit prices agreed with the Bank Group at the start of the project and subject to annual review. In order to facilitate disbursement, Special Account would be opened at a commercial bank acceptable to the Bank Group, with an initial deposit of $6.0 million, representing the average of four months eligible expenditures. Applications for replenishment of these accounts would be submitted monthly or when the account is drawn down to 50 percent of its initial deposit. Retroactive finincing for training and preparation activities necessary for a smooth start- up of the project, up to SDR 5.8 million ($8.4 million equivalent), would be made against expenditures made between October 15, 1995 and the date of signing of the Loan/Credit Agreement. 3.42 The project is expected to be completed by June 30, 2001, and the closing date would be June 30, 2002. Disbursement experience in China has been favorable and better than Bank-Group-wide and East Asia regional averages. The project disbursement profile is essenlially in line with that for previous agricultural development and institution building projects in China. The estimated disbursement schedule is given in Annex 4 Table 6.1.
 - 37 - J. ACCOUNTS AND AUDITS 3.43 Records of expenditures on civil works, equipment and materials would be maintained individually by the participating seed companies. The records would be consolidated by the project provincial PMOs for review and submission to the CPMO at MOA in Beijing. The provincial PMOs would make sure that the accounts are audited annually and would submit the audit reports to CPMO. The latter office would be responsible for submnitting project consolidated accounts and consolidated audit reports to the Bank Group. Assurances were obtained at negotiations that: (a) the Special Account would be audited annually by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank Group, (b) the provincial PMOs would maintain consolidated accounts for all components for annual aaditing by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank Group, (c) audited accounts for the entire project together with the auditor's report would be submitted to the Bank Group within six months of the close of each calendar year, and (d) the seed companies would have their financial statements audited by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank Group. The consolidated audit report would contain a summary of all the provincial audit reports and audited accounts of MOA's project expenditures. It would include details of withdrawals from the Credit/Loan accounts made on the basis of Statements of Expenditure and the auditor's opinion as to whether such withdrawals were against expenditures eligible for reimbursement by IDA/IBRD. K. LAND AcQUISITION 3.44 Land acquisition under the project by the 31 project seed companies would total only about 39 ha, mainly commercial or unused land. They typically already own the land designated for expansion or will contract with smallholder outgrowers to multiply seeds on their own land. Out of 39 ha, only 1 ha is being farmed by three families. These families would be allocated new farm land of equal quality and would get crop coinpenisation according to applicable Chinese laws. They would not be relocated from their houses. Details can be found in Annex 1, Table 9. Assurances were obtained at negotiationzs that, .if any of the subprojects would involve any resettlement, it has to be carried out according to agreed principles and procedures and, if the numbers of primary affected persons in ary subproject reach 200, the province concerned will submit a resettlement action plan to the Bank Group for review as a condition of eligibility for inclusion of the subproject in the project. L. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS 3.45 The project was classified as a B category. It would not be expected to produce any significant detrimental environmental impacts in the project areas. Standard environmental analysis for subprojects would be conducted by Provincial Environmental Protection Bureaus (PEPBs), as needed, for new and existing facilities. The processing plants have a limited potential for localized water, air and noise pollution within and around the plant buildings, but procurement specifications for processing equipment would maintain air emissions below the national thresholds for particulate matter, and
 - 38 - would include full environmental protection measures to maintain pollution within national EPB standards. The project proposes to treat the effluent of all processing plants and administrative and marketing buildings in septic tanks where necessary or, where possible, to discharge effluent into municipal sewers. The combined effluent at the 31 project locations is estimated to be < 1,000 m3/d with BOD concentration of 350-500 ppm. 3.46 The domestic heating system boilers and seed dryers will generate ash, and it has been standard practice to use this ash in road construction and as an extender in brick manufacture. The disposal of the negligible volumes of ash and clinker generated by project activities should therefore not pose any problem. The cotton delinting plants would use dilute acid foam delinting systems that were developed in the United States to meet EPA standards. Similar plants have been used in China since the mid-1980s. Concentrated acid is diluted for application to the cotton seeds and reacts with cellulose linters to produce hydrolyzed cellulose, mainly sugars, that can be used as animal feed enhancers. The residual acidity in the processed seed is neutralized in the process with an alkali solution. It would be a condition of eligibility for inclusion in the project that each subproject be in compliance with environmental standards acceptable to IDA and with Chinese regulations. Thus, the designs and equipment specifications of the seed processing plants would be reviewed and approved by the relevant PEPB as part of its environmental analysis and clearance of each facility. The PEPBs would monitor that these processing plants maintain at all times the environmental protection standards. 3.47 The improvement and expansion of seed production under the project does not differ from crop production for the same crops, except in terms of additional labor for greater inspection and supervision. Similarly, since the seeds and planting materials produced and distributed would be of crops already in production with variety or genotype being the only change, the works of the project would not significantly change interactions between crop agriculture and the environment. -The fertilizers and agricultural chemicals used in the production of seeds would be standard fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides etc., as used in major agricultural economies for similar types of seed production. All farm chemicals procured through the project would be ICAMA- approved products. Assurances to this effect were obtained at negotiations. Assistance would also be required in bidding documents from chemical suppliers to provide training of safe use, handling and storage in accordance with guidelines acceptable to the Bank Group. Assurances to this effect were obtained at negotiations. Optimal seed coatings and coating systems would be determined during the project with the aid of foreign technical assistance and would be ICAMA-approved products. Seed treatment technologies and chemicals (pesticides) would be the same as those used in the major industrialized countries for the same kinds of seeds. Pesticides applied to seeds usually substitute for pesticides applied in the furrow (i.e., soil) at the time of sowing or sprayed/dusted on young plants, and are favored environmentally, since much less pesticide is required and its placement on the seed ensures that it is positioned where it is needed and not scattered in the soil or atmosphere.
 - 39 - 3.48 Germplasm Conservation and Genetic Diversity. China has been very diligent since the 1950s in collecting and preserving the germplasm of its major crops. Over 200,000 accessions were assembled by 1958 after completion of a national campaign on gerrpplasm collection begun in 1953. Some of these accessions were lost due to inadequate and improper storage so that only 160,000 remained in 1979. A decision was then taken to construct a proper gene bank in Beijing to be operated by the Germplasm Resources Institute of Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (CAAS). The bank was completed in 1983 and a second was begun with support from the Rockefeller Toundation and other sources and completed in 1986. Presently, 350,000 accessions are it, the central gene banks, which are world-class in terms of facilities and information processing. An additional 25 field gene banks have been organized in various areas. As en extra precaution the entire collection is duplicated in another gene bank in a "dry" province. Additional specialized collections of germplasm, e.g., forest species, are under control of other institutes and ministries. The germplasm collections in China admittedly have an cconoinic bias. Recently, however, noneconomic and endangered species in the et -system have received attention. In the fringe areas, when new improved varieties replacc traditional varieties, there might be loss of biodiversity. Therefore the project would encourage participating seed companies to assist germplasm resources institutes in collecting existing species, so as to maintain biodiversity. 3.49 The genetic diversity in crop species in China is about the same as in other countries with a high yield agriculture. The project will have a positive effect on the genetic diversity of the crops involved in several ways. Firstly, commercialization of the seeds sector will increase competition among the companies, which they will address in large part by acquiring or developing proprietary varieties, i.e., varieties that are different from others in the market in ways perceived to be important to farmers. The result will be a more diverse array of varieties available to farmers. Secondly, liberalization of the crop variety examination and registration requirements and procedures will facilitate the importation of varieties from other countries, thus increasing the diversity of varieties. Thirdly, enactment and implementation of a legal framework for the protection of plant variety rights, as seems likely, will provide additional strong incentives for crop improvement, research and development and make feasible the introduction of very important germplasm and transgenetic products.
 - 40 - 4. PROJECT ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT A. PROJECT ORGANIZATION 4.1 Project organization would be quite complex, involving central and provincial authorities. At the central level, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) would be responsible for overall project implementation. MOA would assign responsibility to the Bureau of State Farms (BSF) to oversee the implementation of activities concemned with state farm seed companies and to the Department of Agriculture (DOA) for all other project activities, including strengthening of DOA offices at the central level. Both the BSF and the DOA would delegate responsibility for implementation of provincial-level activities to participating provincial governments, which would deal directly with project seed companies. 4.2 Project Leading Groups (PLGs). PLGs would be as small as possible to maximize efficiency. The central PLG would be chaired by a Vice-Minister of MOA in Beijing and the provincial PLGs by the Vice-Governors responsible for agriculture. The members of the provincial PLGs would be the Directors of the Bureaus of Agriculture (BOAs), the General Managers of the provincial-level BSF, the Directors of the Provincial Academies of Agricultural Sciences, the Managers of the provincial-level Agricultural Bank branches, and the Directors of the Bureaus of Finance. The two groups would have representation from seed companies. PLGs at both levels would coordinate and monitor implementation and resolve any disputes that may arise. They would have a major role to play in the promotion, adoption and implementation of policies related to the seed industry, and they would assume responsibility for ensuring provision of adequate counterpart funds. At negotiations, an assurance was obtained that the PLGs would be maintained with terms of reference, composition and resources acceptable to the Bank Group. 4.3 Project Management Offices. Project management offices would be set up at MOA and in participating provinces to coordinate project implementation. The Central Project Management Office (CPMO) would be staffed with personnel from the DOA and the BSF. It would: (a) assist the Provincial Project Management Offices (PPMOs) in drawing up implementation schedules, (b) coordinate project activities with the line agencies at the national and provincial levels, (c) arrange for combined procurement under ICB or LIB, (d) coordinate overseas training, study tours and technical assistance, (e) assist the PPMOs in withdrawing funds from the Credit/Loan, (f) ensure that consolidated accounts, audits and progress reports are prepared and submitted to the Bank Group on time, (g) undertake project monitoring, evaluation and supervision (para. 4.13), and (h) arrange for the project launch workshop (para. 4.1 1), a mid-term evaluation of the project and a completion report after the project completion (para. 4.13).
 - 41 - 4.4 PPMOs would be staffed with trained and qualified personnel from both the provincial BOAs and BSFs. The PPMOs would assist the seed enterprises in liaison with provincial and central authorities regarding assistance needed to facilitate project implementation. They would also coordinate project works with the CPMO. Assurance was obtained at negotiations that the borrower would maintain and support the CPMO and the PPMOs with terms of reference, composition and resources acceptable to the Bank Group. 4.5 The Ministry of Finance (MOF) would be responsible for the financial management of the project and the maintenance of consolidated financial accounts. In order to ensure the effective implementation of the project, and confirm the terms and conditions of relending of Loan/Credit proceeds, assurances were obtained at negotiations that the Borrower would enter into Project Implementation Arrangements (PIAs) with each project province. Conclusion of at least nine PIAs satisfactory to the Bank Group would be a condition of loan/credit effectiveness. B. PROJECT MANAGEMENT 4.6 The CPMO would assist the project provinces in liaison with design institutions on the designs and technical specifications where identical facilities or processes are to be p.ovided for several seed enterprises. These would include the design and specification of standard seed enterprise administrative buildings, standard seed stores and standard processing buildings. The CPMO would also be responsible for engaging technical assistance to review the designs, flow charts, layouts and technical specifications of the seed processing lines. The TOR for this technical assistance can be found in Annexi. 4.7 Seed company managements would have autonomous responsibility for managing the seed companies, including the state farm seed companies, as the enterprises would be established as limited liability companies or limited liability stock companies under the Chinese Company Law. A condition of eligibility to receive a subloan would be that enterprises would have been established in accordance with this law, that they have established a suitable benefits system for employees, and that they be creditworthy, have a soundfinancial structure and suitable organization and management. 4.8 Some companies, notably state farm zompanies, would produce their own breeder seeds or parent-line seeds. Some state farm companies own and operate the farms producing commercial seed. For most project companies, however, the production of seed would normally be undertaken as at present by individuals contracted under the household responsibility system. Under the project, seed growing would however be closely supervised by technical staff from the seed companies, who would provide extension advice. The companies would supply production inputs on credit to those farmers unable to purchase inputs from the township agroextension centers. The companies would supply foundation or mother seed, together with fertilizer and chemicals not generally available in many counties. Fields would not be subject to routine inspection for certification, but sample fields would be inspected by staff of the
 - 42 - seed companies to monitor physical and genetic purity. Competent technicians would also be responsible for sampling and testing all batches of seed before packing to ensure that the technical description on the seed label is accurate. 4.9 Management of the new independent external quality control agencies will be the responsibility cf the provincial agriculture bureaus. The present seed station staffs will form the core staffs of these new units. The heads of the units will report to the heads of the agriculture bureaus and not to seed companies. Assurance was obtained at negotiations that each project province would introduce, no later than December 31, 1996, a program of random field crop inspection and testing ofpacked seed In the event that a field does not meet the necessary standards of uniformity they would have the responsibility to prevent use of the crop for seed purposes. In the event that a sample of seed failed routine tests they would immediately carry out tests on all packs from the batch and if a sufficient number of samples failed to meet the necessary standards they wgould prohibit sale of seed from the batch. They would also carry out tests on behalf of farmers or groups of farmers in the event that seed fails to meet the specifications on its p ick label. The results of these tests would be used by the farmers in pressing their case for zompensation .-om tiie seed company. C. FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT 4.1 MOF v. uid allocate the IBRD Loan and IDA Credit to the Provincial Bureaus of Finance .o be onlent to the seed companies. The interest rate from MOF to the participating provinces would be 5.5 percent with a repayment period of 20 years, inclusive of 5 years grace period. The participating provinces would onlend funds to eligible seed cornpanies at an interest rate of at least 6.5 percent, with a maturity of up to 20 years, including 5 years of grace; the enterprise would bear foreign exchange risk Assurances were obtained at negotiations to this effect. D. PROJECT LAUNCH WORKSHOP 4.11 The project is complex and involves the introduction of radically new approaches to doing business whereby seed companies would become financially independent units rather than line agencies of government supplying subsidized seed to farmers. To familiarize staff of the seed companies, BOAs, BSFs and PMOs with the project concepts, staff of the Bank Group and local experts would conduct project launch workshops, during the first six months after project approval, in selected provincial capitals. The purpose of the workshops would be to: (a) train staff in the commercial operations of seed businesses, (b) clarify the individual tasks and responsibilities of all staff involved in the project, (c) review seed company implementation plans, and (d) clarify the operational and reporting procedures of the Bank Group. E. TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 4.12 The training program for the project is shown in Annex 9. Each year, the CPMO would submit a detailed plan to the Bank Group for review before the end of the
 - 43 - preceding year. Overseas training and study tours would have to be detailed with objectives, place, time and participants. Assurances were obtained at negotiations that annual overseas training and study tour plans would be submitted to the Bank Group by October 31 of the preceding year for prior approval and all consultants would be hired in accordance with IBRD 's guidelines on the selection and use of consultants. F. SUPERVISION, MONITORING, EVALUATION AND REPORTING 4.13 The project management at the central and provincial levels would monitor project progress. In order to ensure smooth implementation, the CPMO would establish procedures for project supervision. Regular supervision would be carried out to assess the physical, technical and financial aspects of the project. Details of the supervision plan are described in Annex 10. Each seed company has its own implementation plan and progress would be evaluated against that plan. Monitoring indicators, including performance indicators, were established and would be used to evaluate progress under the project. These are (a) completion of the draft seed and plant variety legislation; (b) accession to UPOV and ISTA; (c) development of external quality control offices in the project provinces; (d) successful establishment of seed companies as autonomous commercial entities; and (e) formation of these seed companies of alliances with seed companies in other provinces and countries. The CPMO would assist the PPMOs to evaluate the impact of the project on agricultural production, farm incomes and selected environmental parameters (details in Annex 7). Progress reports would be produced by all PPMOs, summarized by the CPMO and forwarded to the Bank Group every six nonths, by September I of each year for the preceding January-June, and by March I for the preceding July-December. A mid-term review of the project would be undertaken by the CPMO by June 30, 1998 to assess progress according to the key performance indicators, and chart implementation of the project for the remaining period. The CPMO would make a broad assessment of the project's implementation in a draft project completion report to be submitted to the Bank Group no later than six months following the completion of the Credit/Loan disbursement. Assurances regarding the preparation and timing of progress and completion reports and mid-term review were obtained at negotiations.
 - 44 - 5. PRODUCTION, MARKETS AND PRICES A. PRODUCTION 5.1 Incremental Seed Production. The project would result in about 272,600 tons of increased seed production annually at full production (Annex.S, Table 1). The additional seed would likely include 210,997 tons of major grains (hybrid and conventional rice, wheat, hybrid maize and barley), 22,400 tons of oilseeds (rapeseed, peanuts, and soybeans), 39,200 tons of cash crops (cotton, vegetables, melons and other crops), and 480,000 seedlings (fruit and flowers). Among the grains, hybrid maize seed would entail the largest increment (64,000 tons). Wheat seed, just behind hybrid maize, would increase by 46,700 tons. Hybrid rice seed would increase by 48,500 tons, while conventional rice seed would increase by 32,700 tons. Increments of cash crops would be led by cotton seed (35,000 tons) and those of oilseeds by hybrid rapeseed (2,700 tons), peanuts (9,700 tons) and soybean (9,900 tons). Vegetable and melon seeds in eight provinces would increase by 4,200 tons. Barley seed would be increased by 18,600 tons. Other seeds (kenaf, grass seeds, herb seeds and sugar beet seeds) would be increased by 4,430 tons. 5.2 Incremental Product. The main objective of the project is to increase product yield through improved seed quality, including that of existing seed production. The incremental product would be derived from a combination of an increase in overall crop yields due to greater varietal purity and reduced seed requirements due to higher germination rates. Commercially purchased seed would replace the seed previously retained for seed by farmers from their own production, thus freeing up this quantity for consumpticn or sale. The incremental volume of improved seed would replace unimproved or retained seed on about 6.3 million ha, including 1.6 million ha of hybrid rice, 0.2 miilion ha of conventional rice, 0.3 million ha of wheat, 1.4 million ha of hybrid maize, 0.3 million ha of rapeseeds, 0.7 million ha of cotton seeds, .05 million ha of peanuts, 0.13 million ha of soybean and 1.4 million ha of vegetables. Incremental crop production due to the project is expected to be 10.9 million tons (3.2 and 7.6 million tons for grains and other crops, respectively). Detailed incremental yield and production can be found in Annex 5, Tables 1-3. B. MARKETS 5.3 Overall the marketing of improved seed is not expected to present major difficulties. Restrictions on marketing previously imposed on the seed market, especially on intercounty and interregional trade, would be removed under the policy reforms introduced under the project. In 1994, the formal seed sector provided only 3.5 million tons of seed, which was only 25 percent of the national seed requirement of 12.5 million
 - 45 - tons. The inciernental volume of seed and seedlings to be produced would be substantial, but in the context of total demand within China, it would be only 1.5 percent of the total demand for seeds. Most currently traded seed is of poor quality and is not expected to present much competition. Grain seed other than hybrids is primarily marketed locally. Vegetable seeds, especially specialty varieties, such as the Chinese cabbage seed of Zibo County, are marketed in considerable amounts outside the region of production, with prefessional traders taking an active distribution role. Cash-crop seed marketing varies with the varieties, some, e.g., cotton, only being supplied locally and others being sold to seed companies in other provinces. 5.4 Locally, some marketing problems may arise. No seed companies have undertaken any formal market research, and only a few have established marketing arrangements with seed companies in other provinces. Almost certainly some project companies will experience difficulties in building up their local market share and will face unanticipated competition from other suppliers in the interprovincial market. As part of their business development plan (para. 2.40), all seed companies have to develop marketing strategies. Some have already started the marketing process and obtained purchase commitments from seed companies in other provinces. One particular area of opportunity is to sell to provinces with no local sources of high-quality seed of the particular varieties involved but which have not imported seed in the past. 5.5 Domestic Demand. Demand for high quality seed has been growing rapidly, reflecting increased product demand due to population and income growth and farmers switching to imp,oved seed. The government policy of ensuring food supply and maintaining per capita grain production of 450 kg per capita has put pressure on increasing agricultural productivity, which can only be achieved through better seeds. S.C Corn is a prime example of this policy. At present, 75 percent of the corn area already uses hybrid corn seed and must purchase seed every year. The government's target is to increase usage to 95 percent, which would increase demand by 19 percent. The higher quality seed produced under the project would find a ready market, since the incremental production of 65,000 tons under the project would only be 17 percent of total requirements. 5.7 Domestic demand for hybrid rice declined during the last few years, but has started to pick up again this year. The decline was due to the low quality of many varieties of hybrid rice seed, and the more discriminating purchases of higher income consumers. The pick up is due to the improved hybrid varieties now available, including hybrid glutinous rice, which is in high demand in the northern provinces. In general, there is considerable room to improve hybrid rice seed to achieve higher yield, resistance to disease and better product flavor. With increased commercialization, the seed enterprises under the project would need to take account of particular regional demands for various hybrid varieties.
 - 46 - 5.8 The government is also promoting the use of hybrid rice seeds and has targeted an increase in the area under hybrid rice from 45 percent to 70 percent. The incremental high quality hybrid rice seed under the project would only be 12 percent of the total incremental demand for hybrid rice and marketing problems are not expected. 5.9 The demand for high quality conventional cereal seeds (rice, wheat) is expected to be significantly increased due to the desire to increase yields. Most seed for conventional varieties is produced by farm households for self-use, but this practice entails declining yields as varietal purity degenerates. Farmers then purchase seed to replace their retained seed with pure varieties and restart the cycle. Progressive farmers, now typically on a three-year cycle are moving to a two-year cycle, and the average farmers are also decreasing their seed replacement period. 5.10 The demand for high quality cotton seed is also expected to increase. This is due to the greater profitability under the new higher cotton price and higher demand for cotton lint from the textile industry. Very poor germination rates of cotton seed due to poor seed quality is a factor in the current high seeding rates which resulted in the shortage of cotton seed. Farmers typically save their own seeds, but with higher purchasing prices, better seed produces better returns and provides the incentive to invest more in seeds. Germination of cotton seed would be improved with the acid delinting seed produced under the project. 5.11 Vegetable production has increased substantially during the last few years due to high market demand and prices. Vegetables are the only crop category that can be traded freely in both crop and seed. Hybrid vegetable seed is immensely superior to retained seed of local varieties, and demand for the hybrids is growing rapidly. In 1994, 1.2 million tons of vegetable seeds were sold for the growing area of 4.5 million ha of vegetables. The demand for seed is expected to increase rapidly, due to an increase in the area under cultivation, especially around cities, and an increase in investment in greenhouse production. 5.12 Interpirovincial Trade. Theoretically, restrictions on interprovincial trade in seed have beeii removed. However, a national seed market has not yet formed, and local protection still. exists in some areas. Clear seed policy statements by the government would be required to end such practices and facilitate interprovincial trade. Currently interprovincial trade, or so-called "varietal exchange", continues to be largely on barter terms arnong long-term clients, and seed companies lack information about market demand and supply. Vegetable seed is an exception, in which interprovincial trade is quite active and market information is obtained from an annual seed fair in Wuhan, Hubei, in which more than 5,000 vegetable producers and traders participate. Factors limiting the clevelopment of interprovincial trade in grain seed include inadequate transportation and an administrative requirement of three years' testing by seed companies befDre new varieties of grain seed can be introduced into a region.
 - 47 - 5.13 All participating seed companies have proposed to increase their sales to interprovincial markets, and when the new seed policies are fully implemented it is expected that trends will be similar to those in the vegetable market. On average, 30-40 percent of the incremental production under the project would be sold to interprovincial and international markets. 5.14 Export Market. Until recently, Chinese seed exports have been very limited and are still small. The most extensive development has been in the vegetable seed trade through the agency of joint ventures with intemational businesses, and exports of vegetable seed are now significant. Chinese vegetable seed producers have become members of the International Federation for Seed Trade (FIS). 5.15 Several factors have inhibited the development of other seed exports. China's previous disinclination to join intemational seed organizations or meet intemational export standards is one. For instance, grain seed exports have not become significant, because China has not met the standards of the OECD Scheme for Seed Certification. However, border trade with Viet Nam and Korea is active in border provinces such as Guangxi and Liaoning. China's delay in joining the Intemational Union for the Protection of Plant Varieties (UPOV) has also inhibited the import of germplasm for production and export. A second factor inhibiting exports in the past has been the seed trade monopoly of the China National Seed Corporation (CNSC). This monopoly has now been abolished, and all seed enterprises are free to develop intemational business. The project would encourage project seed companies to enter the intemational market. 5.16 Joint Ventures. Although there are very few joint venture seed companies in China at present, the initial ventures in vegetable seed have shown the profitability of international trade. A major deterrent to joint ventures has been the absence of plant breeder's rights. The Chinese government is now focusing its attention on this issue, which is closely related to other aspects of property rights reform. Many of the project seed companies have expressed interest in establishing joint venture companies and producing and marketing proprietary germplasm from foreign breeders. A number of international seed companies are also interested in improved Chinese germplasm and willing to negotiate with potential Chinese partners. C. PRICES 5.1 7 Grain Prices. A three-tier system of prices still applies in grain marketing: administered or "quota" prices for the portion of the crop that each farmer must deliver to the State (in effect a form of taxation or rent payable for the use of the farmland), "negotiated" prices, which apply to the part of the crop that the Government buys from farmers over and above the quota, and free market prices. Administered prices have been periodically adjusted in response to inflation, following a sharp increase in free market prices in the preceding year (see Annex 5, Table 6). This led to increases in average producer prices from 1993 to 1994: for rice (in eight selected provinces) 91 percent, for wheat (seven provinces) 65 percent, and for corn (six provinces) 35 percent.
 - 48 - 5.18 Seed Prices. The price of seeds of basic grains in the past has been set in accordance with rigid central government rules, the price paid to growers being linked by fixed ratios to commercial grain prices, which allowed the seed companies a minimal markup. The ratios have in fact served more as guidance than as rules, and- in practice actual markups have been determined by policy decisions at various national and provincial levels, with the result that seed prices differ substantially from one province to another. In general, the prices of processed grain seed (but not that of other crops) have been too low to enable profitable processing. At present, although the market has been liberalized and seed companies have the authority to adjust prices without administrative permission, some governments continue to control seed marketing and prices. An understanding was obtained at negotiations that the Government would continue to relax price control and that seed companies under the project would be allowed to pursue competitive and market-oriented pricing strategies. 5.19 Hybrid Seeds. The ratio of the price of hybrid seed to commercial grain is much higher than that of conventional seed, reflecting the higher production cost. In normal years, for hybrid rice, the ratio has been 6-8:1, whereas for hybrid corn, it has been 34:1. However, when the demand for seed has been high, the ratio has jumped to 10 or more to one. In 1994, the price of hybrid rice seed varied between 12-17 Yuan per kg in different provinces. 5.20 Conventional Seeds. The price ratio for conventional seeds (conventional rice and wheat) has been 1.2-1.5:1. The price ratios of other kinds of seeds, like peanuts, cotton seed, soybean and rapeseed have also fallen in this administrative category. 5.21 Vegetable Seeds. The prices of vegetable seed are free to vary according to rmarket supply anid demand. Prices vary from Yuan 400/kg for sweet pepper seed to Yuan 8/Kg for garlic seeds. Other vegetable prices are listed in Annex 5, Table 7. D. FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 5.22 Financial analysis has been carried out for all selected seed companies. Costs and benefits are derived from the individual business development plans, and are based on the inciZmental costs and benefits of the preproject existing companies. Costs were separated into investment and operating costs. Investrnent costs include those of land development, building construction, equipment, materials and incremental working capital. Unit costs are based on the prevailing domestic prices for locally procured items and international prices for imported items, with all costs updated to 1995 values. Unit costs also include import duties and value added tax (VAT) on all ICB procured materials and equipment. Locally procured items attract VAT only. Tax and duties amount to approximately 24 percent of capital investment cost. Physical contingencies are included as part of investment cost. Working capital estimates are based on requirements for unprocessed seed storage, consumable materials in stock, work in progress (including field crop production where relevant), processed and packed production in stock, and accounts payable for one month including water, power, fuel, salaries and insurance.
 - 49 - 5.23 Operating costs included fixed and variable operating costs, including charges on borrowed working capital. Fixed operating costs include social and welfare bonuses estimated at 11 percent of staff salaries, overhead at 2.5 percent of full production turnover, insurance at 1.5 percent of capital investment and marketing costs at 3 percent ef full production turnover. Annual maintenance cost is included at 2 percent of building costs, 10 percent of vehicle costs and 3 percent of equipment costs. 5.24 Incremental benefits calculated for financial analysis are based on the price differentials the companies receive from producing high quality seed. The margin between the wholesale price of seed and the price that a company paid to contract farmers is considered revenue to the company. An example of the financial analysis of a participating seed company can been found in Annex 5, Table 9. 5.25 Financial Rate of Return (FRR). FRR was calculated, based on the above cost and benefit assumptions for all seed companies. The FRRs ranged from 20 percent to 30 percent. The overall FRR of all subcomponents is estimated at 27 percent. A summary of FRRs for all participating companies can be found in Annex 5, Table 8. Each company has to produce a FRR of at least 20 percent at full operating capacity in order to cover taxes and debt service payments and to allow growth in retained earnings of the organization. Having a FRR of at least 20 percent was also a criterion for qualification as a participating subproject. 5.26 Sensitivity Analysis. Sensitivity analysis was carried out for all seed enterprises to establish the effect on FRR of changes in major variables, such as prices, investment costs and operating costs. These variables were also tested against changes in production volume varying from full capacity of 100 percent down to 80 percent The results of the analysis show that all the FRRs are not very sensitive to changes in prices, costs and production. (Details can be found in Annex 5, Table 8.)
 - 50 - 6. BENEFITS, JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS A. BENEFITS 6.1 The major benefits of this project would be threefold. At the sector level, an environment conducive to commercial development would be developed through policy and regulatory reforms. At the enterprise level, a core group of seed companies would learn to develop profitable commercial business in response to domestic and international commercial demand. At the farm level, there would be an improvement in farm production, yield and incomes. 6.2 The reforms in seed policy would vitalize the seed sector in several ways. First, they would facilitate the elimination of the present monopoly-ridden commercial environment by promoting intercounty and interprovincial trade. Second, by streamlining the examination and registration system and authorizing seed production outside breeding areas, they would facilitate commercial activity by expediting the movement of new cultivars into commerce. Third, as a result of the introduction of improved quality control procedures, they would make a major contribution to the overall improvemenit in the standards and quality of agricultural seed produced and sold in China. Fourth, the development and implementation of a legal framework for the protection of plant breeder rights wouid stimulate plant breeding activities within the country since ownership of new cultivars would be possible and institutes could set reasonable prices for new products. 6.3 Fifth, the inflow of foreign germplasm to China would increase due to domestic companies seeking new and improved genetic materials from abroad and foreign firms seeking more business ventures, knowing that their property rights would be protected. Domestic seed enterprises would also seek cooperation with international seed breeders to combine the improved Chinese varieties with the improved foreign germplasm. Through the broadening of the germplasm base and the establishment of research cooperation vith foreign companies, seed companies with integrated research, production and marketing functions would probably develop as they exist in most western countries. 6.4 Participating companies would have a chance to develop into profitable, independent companies with clearly defined structures and ownership. The companies would be managed by trained management teams with responsibility for planning, production and marketing. Due to their profitability, the companies would be able to pay taxes and retain cash flow for future expansion. The transparency of structure, ownership and management would facilitate the flow of foreign capital into joint ventures to produce seeds for export. International companies would also be expected to significantly
 - 51 - increase their presence in the Chinese market through variety licensing, variety registration and breeding cooperation. 6.5 The major quantifiable benefits from the project would be in the area of incremental production resulting from the improved quality of seeds. The introduction of new germplasm would lead to further yield increases of crops such as hybrid rice and corn. The latter could increase by 10-20 percent, based on yields currently achieved in China compared with those of France and the United States. In addition, good quality seed would reduce the existing excess seeding rates. For instance, farmers would save about 90 kg/ha when hybrid rice seed is used instead of conventional rice and would save 5 kg/ha when improved hybrid rice seed is used instead of ordinary hybrid rice. Acid delinted cotton seed would save about 15 kg/ha of cotton seed. Improved varieties of wheat would reduce the seeding rate by 30 kg/ha, and improved corn would reduce the seeding :ate by 5 kg/ha. In total, the saving from using improved hybrid seed would be about Y 126 million ($15 million) per year for the project area. 6.6 The total incremental production would be 3.2 million tons of grains (rice, wheat, corn, and barley), 316,000 tons of oil crops (rapeseed, peanuts and soybean), 280,000 tons of cotton and 7 million tons of vegetables. Total seed saved is estimated at 49,000 tons. The annual financial value of incremental production would be Y 10.0 billion ($1.2 billion), while the annual economic value would be Y 14.6 billion ($1.7 billion) based on economic prices (Annex 5, Table 1). The net economic value would be Y 7.8 billion ($0.98 billion) (Annex 6, Table 8.2). B. EMPLOYMENT AND INCOMES 6.7 At the farm level, the demand for labor for planting would be reduced due to less seed being used. However, the demand for labor would be increased in the areas of crop maintenance and harvesting due to higher yields. The incremental demand for labor is assumed to be met from household laborers. Additional employment may be created for harvesting and post harvesting activities. The seed companies would provide 1,360 new jobs in the seed processing industry in 31 modernized seed processing plants, and I seed machinery plant. 6.9 The project would have a positive impact on the incomes of project beneficiaries. Farm budget analysis indicates that net income would be increased due to better yield and production. For example, in Guangxi, the net farm income per hectare of hybrid rice would be increased from Y 4,51b ($538) to Y 5,437 ($647), from Y 1,870 ($223) to Y 3,073 ($365) for hybrid com and from Y 3,759 ($448) to Y 7,268 ($865) for peanuts. Farm budget analysis for each province is summarized in Annex 6, Table 1. Farm model analysis shows that per capita income of farmers in Guangxi would be increased from Y 414 ($49) to Y 640 ($76) with the project, an increment of Y 226 ($27) or 35 percent. The average per capita income of the project's farmers as a whole would be increased from Y 580 ($69) to Y 905 ($108), an increment of Y 325 ($39) or 56 percent. Results of farm model analysis by province are summarized in Annex 6, Table 3.
 - 52- C. COST RECOVERY 6.9 Cost recovery for this project would come from service fees and tax revenue from the seed companies and incremental crop production. Fees would be established for seed registration, certification and testing services. Assurance was obtained at negotiations that the Borrower would develop, no later than December 31, 1997, a fee system for variety testing and registration, field inspection and seed testing to cover the cost of these services. Such system would be introduced no later than June 30, 1998 in at least six Project Provinces, with a view to introducing such systems nationwide no later than June 30, 2000. A draft of the proposal would be reviewed at the project launch workshop. The cost of external quality control, research and extension would be recovered through the 5 percent provincial crop tax which would be imposed on the incremental crop production under the project. 6.10 The government would receive incremental tax revenue from the VAT and the corporation tax levy by the central government and City Construction Tax levied locally. The companies would generate total annual tax revenue of Y 280 million of which Y 110 million would be VAT, Y 160 million corporation tax and Y 10 million city tax. The seed companies would be responsible for repaying the principal plus interest on their borrowings. Repayments to MOF would be guaranteed by all participating project provinces. D. IMPACT ON GOVERNMENT BUDGET 6.11 The total incremental recurrent budget required to keep the project seed stations operating at the same level of efficiency following the loan disbursement period is estimated at Y 6.5 million ($0.8 million). The percentage impact of this incremental recurrent expenditure on the administrative budgets of the 13 provinces is very small. E. ECONOMIc ANALYSIS 6.12 Economic analysis has been carried out for each province and for the project as a whole. As described in paras. 6.5-6.6, the economic benefits of the project would come from: (a) the net value of incremental grain production resulting from better varieties of seed, and (b) the saving of seed from the use of higher quality seed at recommended seeding rates. The incremental economic benefit is estimated from per hectare incremental production based on farm budget analysis of the future situation with and without the project, using economic prices for inputs and outputs (Annex.6, Table 7). The net economic value of annual potential incremental production would be Y 7.8 billion per annum, on the assumption that 100 percent of the farmers using improved seeds in the project area would achieve the expected incremental yield. 6.13 The total hectarage for each crop in each province is estimated on the basis of incremental seed production under the project. The incremental economic values by province are shown in An= 6, Table 8. Project costs include all project investment costs for seed companies and seed stations (excluding the MOA project office and the
 - 53 - Shanghai Xiangmin Machinery Company) and the fixed and variable operating costs of the seed companies, the incremental recurrent cost of the seed stations, the incremental farm production costs and an allowance for physical contingencies. Buildings are assumed to last 20 years and vehicles and equipment 7-8 years. Recurrent costs are assumed to continue at the same level for the remainder of the 20-year period as during project Year 6. 6.14 World price projections or average export prices actually realized by China in 1995 were used to estimate constant farm-gate economic prices for traded inputs and outputs (Aanex 6, Table 5). Economic prices for nontraded goods were estimated using conversion factors (Annex 6, Table 6) based on the analysis of the deviations of social opportunity costs from the actual financial prices prevailing in China, which are caused by taxes and price distortions. All economic values were converted to local currency at the prevailing official exchange rate of Y 8.4 to $1. 6.15 A conservative approach was made in claiming the benefits of the project. In general, a concentrated area development effort would be needed to realize the full benefits of an agricultural project. Since seed production under the project would be used in extensive areas, it is unlikely that the full incremental benefit would be totally achieved without such efforts. For instance, farmers may not have access to the inputs or support services that would be necessary to fully exploit the benefit of improved seeds. Furthermore, it is difficult to disaggregate the result of improved seeds from that of improved irrigation, input supply, marketing and credit. Hence, for this economic analysis, benefits attributed to improved seed are assumed to be only 25 percent of the net potential incremental value of production. Based on the above, the economic rates of return of investment in each province range from 18 percent to 77 percent. The project's economic rate of return is estimated at 42 percent, with a net present value of Y 1.7 billion ($205 million). A summary of the analysis can be found in Annex 6, Table 9. 6.16 Sensitivity analysis has been carried out to evaluate the sensitivity of the project's ERR to price and cost variations. The project is not very sensitive to an increase in investment and operating costs; if the investment costs increased by 10 percent, the ERR would be reduced to 39 percent, and if the operating cost increased by 10 percent, ERR would be reduced to 30 percent. Labor cost has a very small impact on the ERR; 10 percent and 20 percent increases in labor costs would reduce ERR to 41 percent and 40 percent, respectively. However, the ERR is sensitive to prices of output: if price falls by 10 percent, ERR would be reduced to 24 percent. 6.17 Sensitivity analysis has also been carried out to identify the minimum incremental value of production due to seeds that would still result in a satisfactory ERR. Usage would have to drop to a very low 20 percent of farmers to bring the ERR down to 12 percent, the opportunity cost of capital. If 30 percent of farmers achieved the expected yields, the ERR would increase to 74 percent. A summary of the sensitivity analysis can be found in Annex 6, Tables 10-16.
 - 54 - F. RisKs 6.18 A risk with respect to the policy framework would be that not all of the measures under the draft seed sector policy would be approved by the Government. This is lessened by the open reiteration of this policy in several high-level speeches and the initiation of several key activities to achieve this policy by the Government. Seed sector modernization and commercialization is also the main thrust in the new government's Seed Industrialization Program. In the project, seed companies are being restructured to be independent companies under the Chinese Company Law. Policy actions to separate seed administration from seed commercialization have already been achieved in more than 10 provinces. The new seed law and a legal framework for plant variety protection is being drafted. And, finally, the price of seed is now set according to market conditions, and interprovincial trade for seed has become significant. 6.19 A risk with respect to the legal framework would be a significant delay in enacting the seed law and the legal framework for plant variety protection. This is lessened by the strong government commitment to seed commercialization and the desire to enter the international seed trade. The first drafts of the seed law and the legal framework for plant variety protection are being refined and are expected to be submitted to the State Council by the end of this year. The risk of poor regulatory follow-through in implementing the law and regulation is lessened by the involvement of provincial governments in the drafting and the government's plan to draft implementing particulars. 6.20 The risk that no effective, profitable seed companies will emerge or they will decline to compete outside of traditional boundaries is reduced by the selection process already undertaken. It would be further reduced by the improved business environment and by technical assistance to firms in business practice and management. The risk of ineffective financial management would be minimized by training and institutional development financed under the project. The risk of nonavailability of new superior products would be minimized by the ability to access new genetic materials via international trade. Production risk is very small since seed has been produced for several millennia in China.

AGREEMENTS AND RECOMMENDATION 7.1 At negotiations, assurances were obtained from the Government that: (a) The participating provinces would onlend funds to eligible seed companies at an interest rate of at least 6.5 percent, with a maturity of 20 years, including 5 years' grace; the enterprise would bear the foreign exchange risk. Subloans would only be made to enterprises and to subprojects that meet the agreed eligibility criteria (paras. 2.41, 3.44, 3.47, 4.7 and 4.10); (b) Project Implementation Arrangements (PIAs) would be concluded between the Borrower and the 14 provinces when they (i) have separated the quality control functions from their seed companies and (ii) propose to make at least one eligible subloan to a seed company (para. 2.42); (c) A condition of disbursement for the seed stock under a given subproject would be that operation plans for the subproject acceptable to the Bank Group have been prepared and the subproject's seed processing lines are installed and ready for operation (para. 3.41); (d) Special account(s) would be audited annually by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank Group, the provincial PMOs would maintain consolidated accounts for all components for annual auditing by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank Group, audited accounts together with the auditor's report would be submitted to the Bank Group within six months of the close of each year, and the seed companies would have their financial statements audited by independent auditors acceptable to the Bank Group (para. 3.43); (e) If any of the subprojects have any resettlement, it has to be carried out according to principles and procedures acceptable to the Bank Group and, if the numbers of primary affected persons in any subproject reach 200, the province concerned will submit a resettlement action plan to the Bank Group for review as a condition of eligibility for inclusion in the project (para. 3.44); (f) All farm and seed coating chemicals procured through the project would be ICAMA-approved products. Chemical use, handling and storage would be according to guidelines acceptable to the Bank Group (para. 3.47); (g) The PI,Gs would be maintained with terms of reference, composition and resources acceptable to the Bank Group (para. 4.2);
 - 56 - (h) It would maintain and support the CPMO and the PPMOs with terms of reference, composition and resources acceptable to the Bank Group (para. 4.4); (i) Each project province would introduce, no later than December 31, 1996, a program of random field crop inspection and testing of packed seed (para. 4.9); (j) Annual oveiseas training and study tour plans would be submitted to the I-P,-k Group foi prior approval and all consultants would be hired in accordance with IBRD's guidelines on the selection and use of consultants (para. 4.12); (k) Progress reports would be produced by all PPMOs, summarized by the CPMO and forwarded to the Bank Group every six months. A mid-term review of the project would be undertaken by the CPMO by June 30, 1998 to assess progress and chart implementation of the project for the remaining period (para. 4.13); and (1) The Borrower would establish, no later than December 31, 1997, a fee system for variety testing and registration, field inspection and seed testing to cover the cost of these services. Such system would be introduced no later than June 30, 1998 in at least six Project Provinces, with a view to introducing such system nationwide no later than June 30, 2000 (para. 6.9). 7.2 Condition of Effectiveness. The Borrower would enter into Project Implementation Arrangements (PIAs) with at least nine project provinces satisfactory to the Bank Group as a condition of Loan/Credit effectiveness (para. 4.5). 7.3 Subject to the above conditions, the proposed project would constitute a suitable basis for an IBRD loan of $80 million with 20 years' maturing including 5 years of grace at the Bank's standard interest rate for LIBOR-based US dollar single currency loans, and an IDA credit of SDR 13.8 million, equivalent to $20 million, at IDA's standard terms with a 35-year maturity, to the People's Republic of China.

This enterprise is a State Farm company that manufactures a wide range of agricultural machinery and seed processing equipment. The company has provided seed processing lines to 20 county seed companies under the World Bank financed Henan ADP. Their existing equipment range is well constructed, and the company offers an excellent service to their clients including installation, training, and servicing contracts. 90. Their equipment designs and manufacturing procedures lack some of the technical advantages of top class imported equipment. In particular the company lacks good designs for key equipment such as air screen separators and gravity tables that form the basis of good seed separating systems. They also do not have the required high quality machine tools, screen presses and perforators to produce accurate drum separators and screens. The mechanical "doffers" that clean the air screens during operation in their present range of seed separators are far less efficient than the latest rubber ball cleaners now used in imported equipment. 91. Gravity separator tables produced by this company also need an improved control system to gain the accuracy and reliability of foreign machines. The company does not have computer aided design (CAD) facilities that are now used by most suppliers to produce plant layout drawings to each clients requirements, or the computer aided manufacturing (CAM) equipment that translates the CAD designs into shop floor manufacturing instructions. 92. The company has approached several major European seed equipment manufacturers for either a joint venture agreement or a license agreement that would enable the company to upgrade its seed processing machinery to the latest technology. They have received a interest from a number of companies that might license equipment manufacture to the Shanghai Company, or would use the company as sales and service agents. 93. The Shanghai company would therefore invest under the project in construction of a new workshop, the necessary machine tools, CAD/CAM design and manufacturing equipment and in one or more technical collaboration agreements to upgrade their seed processing equipment technology and production facilities. This component of the project is an important step in assisting the China seeds
 Annex 1 - 69 - Page 13 of 17 sector to progress in terms of processing system technology, and would have a significant long term effect on the seeds sector. 94.
