The project would also provide 3 vehicles and 3 items of agricultural machinery, 350 tons of fertilizer and 3 tons of farm chemicals. Training would include 20 mm local training and 4 mm foreign training, and 0.5 mm foreign study tour. 119. The project would invest Y14.7 million in capital investment excluding contingencies, and Y356,000 in working capital. The investment would produce a turnover of Y14.4 million and 21.1% FIRR at full rated capacity, and 16.2% FIRR at 80% of rated capacity. The component would maintain a stable FIRR with normal variations in market conditions. Capital growth would be good from project year 4, resulting in cumulative net income of Y13.5 million in 20 years, after tax, debt servicing and dividend payments. Follow-Up : This component has been well prepared, and there are no specific follow-up actions before the Project Launch Workshop. Henan Xu Chang State Farm. 120. This company would produce and market 4,362 tons/year of seeds of which 3,164 t/y would be wheat, and 1,198 t/y of Hlybrid Maize. The company would provide employment for 25 permanent staff at their offices, laboratories and processing facilities, in addition to seasonal labor at the processing plant and farmers at the production base. 121. The investment planned by the enterprise would include the provision of borewells and power lines, development of 3,000 m2 of seed drying floor, 900 m2 of seed stores, and an enterprise center. Processing equipment would include one 3t/h seed processing line with one double head packing line for 25kg and 50kg sacks. Offices would be provided with office equipment, computers, training equipment and internal quality control facilities. The project would also provide 3 vehicles, 3 tractore, 9 items of agricultural equipment, 300 tons of fertilizer and 10 tons of farmr chemicals. Training would include 10 mm local training and lmm foreign training. 122. The project would invest Y9.7 million in capital investment excluding contingencies, and Y 73,000 in working capital. The investment would produce a turnover of Yl6.4 million and 21.1% FIRR at full rated capacity, and 14.9% FIRR at 80% of rated capacity. The component would maintain a stable FIRR with normal variations in market conditions, but a 10% reduction in sales margins would reduce the FIRR to 7.7%. Capital growth would be good from project year 5, resulting in cumulative net income of Y8.5 million in 20 years, after tax, debt servicing and dividend payments. Follow-Up : The building designs and site layout drawings prepared by the company needed improvement and suggestions for a practical layout were agreed with all storage, processing and utilities in one building. New drawings are to be prepared by the State Farm and presented at the Project Launch Workshop. The component has otherwise been well prepared.
 - 73 - Annex 1 Page 17 of 17 Henan Huana Fan Ou State Farm. 123. This company would produce and market 6,555 t/y of seeds of which 3,341 t/y would be wheat seeds and 3,214 t/y of peanut seeds. These two products would be harvested at different seasons and would allow a longer than average processing period at the plant. The company would provide employment for 40 permanent staff at their offices, laboratories and processing facilities, in addition to seasonal labor at the processing plant and farmers at the production base. 124. The investment planned by the enterprise would include land preparation, development of 6,000 m2 of seed drying floor, 1600 m2 of seed stores, 560 m2 processing and packing rooms, an enterprise center, utilities room, and 4 retail shops. Processing equipment would include one 3t/h seed processing and packing line for jute sacks. Offices would be provided with office equipment, computers, training equip.nent and internal quality control facilities. The retail shops would be fitted out with a standard set of retailing equipment and materials. The project would also provide 3 vehicles, 8 tractors, 1,000 tons of fertilizer and 20 tons of farm chemicals. License agreements would be made with local institutes for improved seed varieties, and this would be funded from Counterpart Funds. Training would include 13 mm local training and 2mm foreign study tours. 125. The project would invest YI8.4 million in capital investment excluding contingencies, and Y302,000 in working capital. The investment would produce a turnover of Y23.6 million and 22.4% FIRR at full rated capacity, and 17.1% FIRR at 80% of rated capacity. The component would maintain a stable FIRR with normal variations in market conditions, but a 10% reduction in sales margins would reduce the FIRR to 12%. Capital growth would be good from project year 4, resulting in cumulative net income of Y22 million in 20 years, after tax, debt servicing and dividend payments. Follow-Up : The building designs and site layout drawings prepared by the company needed considerable improvement and suggestions for a practical layout were agreed with all storage, processing and utilities in one building. New drawings are to be prepared by the State Farm and presented at the Project Launch Workshop.

 Annex 2 - 86 - Page 1 of 3 CHINA SEED SECTOR COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT PLANTER BOX SEED SURVEYS PURPOSE The purpose of the "Planter Box Seed Surveys" is to survey the quality of seeds of selected crops saved by farmers for planting (the so-called informal seed sector) and to compare the quality of the farmer-saved seeds with that of seeds of the same kind and variety available in the market. GENERAL PROCEDURE The surveys will be made at planting time for the selected crops so that information on seeds actually being planted can be obtained along with a small sample for analysis and testing. CROP SEED KINDS SURVEYED Wheat, soybean and/or conventional rice, i.e., non-hybrid. These are important crops of the self-pollinated type for which seed saving by farmers is a common practice worldwide. It might be difficult to find a suitable area for surveying where conventional rice is planted by a sufficient portion of farmers for convenient survey. If this turns out to be the case, the focus should be on wheat and soybean. Soybean is included because the seeds are more difficult for farmers to save with good maintenance of quality than most other seed kinds. On the other hand, seeds of rice are perhaps the easiest seeds to save with good maintenance of quality. Shandong province is recommended for soybean; Henan for wheat. SURVEY AREAS Representative counties in Shandong (soybean) and Henan (wheat) provinces for each of the two seed kinds to be surveyed should be selected and within each county, one or more villages with a population of several hundred farmers to provide for a good sample of 100 farmers in the field planting during the planting season. The survey would be repeated in the same or an adjacent county the following season in the same manner to provide two 100 farmer samples for each seed kind for total of 200 farmers. SURVEY PERIOD AND NUMBERS - 2 seed kinds (wheat and soybean or conventional rice) - 2 years - 100 farmers per kind per year - 2 seed kinds (areas) x 2 years x 100 farmers/survey = 400 farmers. 400 farmers = 400 samples
 - 87 - Annex 2 Page 2 of 3 ORGANIZATION, COLLABORATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES The surveys should be under the general sponsorship of the Project Management Office in association with the Provincial PMO of the Province or Provinces selected for the surveys. The Provincial Seed Administration(s) or Seed Administrations of the Prefecturate(s) in which the counties to be surveyed are located should be responsible for the surveys with a qualified person assigned as Survey Leader. Collaboration should be established with the major seed company in the area and with the Agrotechnical Extension Centers to assist with selection of the survey areas, accompany and assist the surveyors, provide transportation and be helpful in other ways.. - Personnel of the Provincial or Prefectural Seed Stations would &x'J te farmers, obtain the desired information and collect samples. Transportation would be provided by the pertinent Administration. - The Provincial or Prefectural Seed Testing Laboratory would make the purity and germination analyses of the samples collected. To the extent possible, the purity analyses would include an assessment of varietal purity as well as physical purity, and observations on seed health would be made during the purity analysis and germination test. - The Agrotechnical Extension Center would be responsible for planting out the samples in the field for additional observations on varietal purity. SURVEY PROCEDURES AND EVALUATIONS - Two to four person team would move through survey area during planting season for the crop, identify farmers actually planting the crop or making preparations to plant in the next several days, obtain specified information from the farmer and a sample of the seeds that are or will be planted. The size of seed sample will be 1 kg and the seeds will be replaced with clean. good quality seeds of the same variety. The farmer will be asked to plant the replacment seeds in one location and mark the location with bamboo poles with cloth "flags" at the beginning and end of the replacement seeds. - The information collected from each farmer surveyed would be relatively brief and simple: name and location of field (for followup visit); number of mu to be planted; seeding rate per mu; the variety and source of seed (where did he get the seeds he is planting?, saved himself, from neighbor, from seed company, from extenstion center, other); why did he choose the source of seed that he chose?; why did he choose the variety that is being planted? - The 1 kg samples would be taken at to the seed testing laboratory that will do the work and divided into two 500 g samples. One sample would be used
 - 88 - Annex 2 Page 3 of 3 for purity, germination and other laboratory tests; the other sample would be used for the field planting. The laboratory tests would be made using standard procedures with the additional assessments and observations on varietal purity and seed health as mentioned above. The field tests would be only for obervations on varietal purity and consist of duplicate rows of each sample, 125 -150 seeds per row thinned in seedling stage to approximately 100 plants. Row and plant spacing would be closer than for VCU testing. Varietally pure seeds of each variety represented in the survey (obtained from foundation seed stocks) would be planted in the row before and after the survey rows. The field plantings would be evaluated several times to determine variety purity and make observations on specific diseases. - Followup visits would be made to 25 of the farmers surveyed to observe the performance of the varietally pure, processed and good quality seeds that replaced the seeds taken in the sample. - The survey leader would assemble the results of the laboratory analyses and field evaluations, categorize the samples according to source of seeds (i.e., home-saved, neighbor, seed company, seed station, other) and make appropriate comparisions of quality among the sources of seeds surveyed. Additional data for analysis and comparison could be obtained from laboratory test results of samples of seeds of the same variety for seeds marketed in the county or prefecturate by seed companies and seed stations. REQUIREMENTS The requirements for the surveys would not be great. For an extension effort of these sorts, personnel time ought to be assigned. The remaining requirements would be: transportation costs for the survey; seeds from seed companies operating in the area of the different varieties encountered to replace the 1 kg sample taken from farmer; laboratory supplies and materials for testing; use of equipment, materials and field plots for field tests. An adequate and reasonable budget for essential requirements would be about Y160 per sample. For the two years of the survey, 2 crops, and 100 samples/crop/year, the budget would be: 100 samples x 2 crops x 2 years x 160 = Y64.000 (maximum, it could be nuch less depending on cooperators & cooperation.
 AnngX 3 Page 1 of 7 - 89 - CHINA SEED SECTOR COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT PILOT COMPANIES FOR COMMERCIALIZATION 1. In order tc establish company structures which could serve as models for the commercialization of the Chinese seed sector, 3 pilot companies were identified which will be monitored closely throughout the implementation phase of the Project. The 3 pilot companies are based on current operations of (i) a state farm, (ii) a prefecture seed company, and (iii) a provincial seed company. These companies will be formed as limited liability companies or limited liability stock companies under Chinese Company laws as adopted in December 29, 1993. Operationally, these companies will be structured quite differently and are intended to serve as examples for other entities pursuing the objective of commercialization. Under the Project it is proposed that these pilot companies be provided with additional training and technical assistance to ensure successful conversion to commercialized operations. Monitoring procedures have been identified to ensure that these companies will accomplish their objectives. Zhangqiu State Farm 2. Zhangqiu State Farm (ZSF) is located in the Zhangqiu Prefecture in Shandong Province: ZSF operates on about 8,000 mu (530 ha), half of which is used for the production of grain. The state farm recently concluded an exclusive agreement with the Zhangqiu Municipal Leek Research Institute (ZMLRI) for the representation of new varieties. ZMLRI is the only institute in China involved in the development of new varieties of leek. All leek seed grown commercially in China today is hybrid seed. 3. ZSF originally proposed to operate the seed business as a separate division of the state farm; subsequent to several reviews, however, it was decided that the seed business be spun off the state farm operations and established as a limited liability company, Zhangqiu Leek Seed Company (ZLSC). This company will assume the licensing agreement with ZMLRI and will be responsible for the production and marketing of foundation and commercial seed. ZLSC will contract for all of its seed production requirements; while ZSF will be a preferred seed producer due to its longstanding experience with the production of high quality leek seed, production will also be contracted with other seed producers to ensure a competitive environment. Foundation seed will be marketed under licensing arrangements and commercial seed will be marketed either direct or through representatives in other provinces. 4. Annually China produces leek on about 267,000 ha; at planting rates of 7.5 kg/ha this requires about 2,000 t of commercial seed. This commercial seed can be produced on about 2,600 ha (seed yields of 750 kg/ha) which requires about 20 t of foundation seed (7.5 kg/ha). At foundation seed yields of about 380 k-/ha, 20 t can be produced on about 50 ha. Under the Project, ZLSC plans to market about 20 t of foundation seed annually and to increase sales of commercial seed to about 700 t over 5 years. 5. Leek seed will be the primary product of ZLSC; however, in order to have a minimum of diversification, the company will also market celery seed (about 100 t/year) and radish seeds (about 200 t/year) under agreements with the Institute for Vegetable Seeds in Shandong. 6. As ZLSC will be created as a limited liability company with a minimum of two initial shareholders. Chinese law required limited liability companies and limited liability stock companies to be supervised by a Board of Directors. This board will be composed of one representative each of ZLSC, ZSF, ZMLRI, Zhangqiu City Seed Cc-.pany, and a contract seed producer. Management will report
 An3 - 90 - Page 2 of 7 to this board as management in a shareholding company would report to the board of directors. 7. The general manager of the company will be assisted by two deputies; one being responsible for finance and sales/marketing, the other responsible for seed production and conditioning. The quality assurance function as well as support services will report directly to the general manager. Total company staff will be approximately 50. 8. Of critical importance for the company will be the supply of new, improved germplasm on a regular basis. In the past, release of new varieties in China was rather slow; research institutes constantly made improvements to once released varieties, but they did not change the designation of the product. This policy resulted in the fact that varieties marketed today do no longer truly resemble the characteristics of the original product but they are still marketed under the designation of that original product. This situation will change with the introduction of plant breeders' rights (PBR). - In its negotiations with ZMLRI, ZLSC will ensure that new varieties will be available on a regular basis. ZMLRI will have the responsibility to describe these varieties and to obtain protection under PBR; ZLSC will have the responsibility to ensure varietal purity so that the product which is marketed truly reflects the characteristics as described by ZMLRI. ZLSC will pay a license fee (royalty) to ZMLRI for the right to produce and market the products developed by the institute, and this license will be established as a percentage of the price for which ZLSC sells its seed. This arrangement will significantly change the marketing of seeds; ZLSC will regularly launch new products into the market, they will have to manage "product cycles" including the phasing out of products on the decline. 9. In its seed production operations, ZLSC will have to negotiate contracts which take into account the actual cost of production incurred by the producers plus a small premium for their efforts to produce seed as compared to a commercial crop. Superior quality should demand a higher premium. However, as sales prices for seed will remain rather low in comparison with world market prices for a number of years, it is of utmost importance for all seed companies that they control their seed production cost and attempt to keep them as low as possible. Only this policy will allow them to make a reasonable profit from their operations which can then be reinvested into the business (including research). 10. ZLSC intends to market its seed through 4 sales points within the prefecture as well as through representatives/agents in other regions. One major customer will be Zhangqiu City Seed Company which already today sells several hundred tons of leek seed to provinces such as Liaoning, Anhui, Henan, Shanxi, and others. A brand image and identity for Zhangqiu leek seed has been established. ZLSC must ensure that it uses this brand identity to its advantage while creating its own identity for seed of superior quality. ZLSC will have to segment its markets, particularly in regards to the sale of foundation vs. commercial seed; and ZLSC must very carefully select the customers to whom they sell foundation seed to ensure that the high quality of its foundation seed is maintained in the commercial seed produced by these customers. 11. ZLSC will eutablish its own company internal quality assurance program to ensure that these quality issues are being observed. Thus the quality assurance department has a responsibility not only for the seed produced by the company but also must, from time to time, check the seed produced by the company's licensees. The quality standards established by this quality assurance program will be superior to those established in the official government regulations. 12. Significant training and technical assistance will be provided for ZLSC to ensure that management is equipped with the knowledge and understanding for the company to accomplish its objectives. Also, monitoring procedures and performance indicator- have been identified to measure the companies progress.
 - 91 - PageT-of 7 These will be explained in the summary section. ZiBo Prefecture Seed Company 13. ZiBo Prefecture Seed Company (ZPSC) is located in the city of ZiBo in Shandong province. The company operates with a staff of 50 people, it maintains a central office and seed cleaning facility, a research farm, and 6 retail stores in the municipality of ZiBo. All management staff of ZPSC are agronomists, holding the responsibilities of (i) general manager, also responsible for finance, (ii) vegetable seed sales manager, (iii) wheat and corn sales manager, (iv) manager for buildings/services/engineering, (v) research and production manager. 14. ZPSC developed its proposal for participation in the Project based on an in-house research program for chinese cabbage and the recent acquisition of the production and marketing rights to a corn hybrid. The company suggests that the functions and responsibilities of the seed station have already been separated from its operations; this is yet to be verified. The company intends to continue operating as a stand-alone operation but to increase its market share in hybrid corn and to expand interregional marketing of vegetable seeds. 15. ZPSC will be established as a limited liability company, as with Zhangqiu, the company will have at least two shareholders; and it was suggested to offer a minority interest also to the managers. Management will report to a Board of Directors whose members will represent the shareholders as well as successful local businesses. The land and buildings which the company will operate will be transferred to the company by transfer of a "right to use". These rights will be valued as equity contributions by the shareholders to the capital stock of the company; and the transfer of these rights will be signed off on by local government to ensure that management is autonomous in deciding on the use of these land and buildings. 16. The general manager will report directly to the Board of Directors; he will be assisted by three deputies responsible for (i) seed production and conditioning, (ii) research, foundation seed production, and variety testing, (iii) marketing and sales of seed of Chinese cabbage and hybrid corn. The finance department, the quality assurance department, and the support services will report directly to the general manager. Total company staff will be about 50. 17. In vegetable seeds, ZPSC has about 1,400 accessions of Chinese cabbage as its proprietary germplasm pool; the research effort is directed towards the development of hybrids. Total cost of the research program is about 300,000 Yuan per year. While the company considers its genetic basis as sufficient and its hybrids superior as regards quality and earliness, ZPSC will change its products release policy as described above for Zhangqiu, including protection of new varieties under PBR. ZPSC will also begin significant efforts to identify other sources for improved germplasm nationally and internationally. These products would be secured for the company either through licensing operations or otherwise. 18. In corn seeds ZPSC will also actively pursue new sources for germplasm. Presently the company has a production and marketing right to one corn hybrid developed by Shandong Agricultural Research Institute; under the project the company will explore both national and international breeders for improved products. 19. Concerning seed production, ZPSC will produce all foundation seed of Chinese cabbage and hybrid corn on its own research farm; the technical and management expertise to carry out this production has already been established. Production of commercial seed will be contracted out. The seed production system in the ZiBo prefecture is such that adequate isolation for the production of high
 - 92 - Annex 3 Page 4 of 7 quality seed of different varieties can be guaranteed through contracts with farm-households. 20. ZPSC presently sells about 150 t of cabbage seeds annually, 15 t in the regional market and 135 t in the interregional market; at this level the company is not able to meet market demand. ZPSC projects to increase sales to about 500 t/year. This increase will be accomplished through an expansion of the existing network of representatives/agents throughout China (this network currently extends over 25 provinces throughout the country). ZPSC has already established a proprietary package for "ZiBo Cabbage Seed" which clearly distinguishes it from any other source; this package also has created a brand image for the company in the interregional market. The company will accomplish its sales objectives by building on and expanding this brand identity. - ZPSC presently sells its corn seeds within the prefecture; the company recently concluded contractual arrangements with 6 county seed companies to sell ZPSC corn seeds exclusively under the Project. ZPSC will also pursue sales opportunities outside the prefecture, most likely through some of its vegetable seed dealers. Following this strategy the company should accomplish its projected sales increase of corn seeds from 500 t to 5,000 t annually. 21. ZPSC will establish and strengthen its own company internal quality assurance program to ensure that the highest possible seed quality is produced and sold. As the acreage to carry out the projected production will be rather large, the company will work with local staff in the various seed production communities which are not permanent employees but supervise production on account of and according to the standards of the company. The quality standards implemented by the company will be superior to the standards established for the external governmental quality control inspections. 22. Significant training and technical assistance will be provided for ZLSC to ensure that management is equipped with the knowledge and understanding for the company to accomplish its objectives. Also, monitoring procedures and performance indicators have been identified to measure the companies progress. These will be explained in the summary section. Guangxi Provincial Seed Company 23. Guangxi Provincial Seed Company (GSC) is located in Nanning, the capital of Guangxi Province; with 83 million people this province is the third most populated province of China. Until 1995 GPSC still operated much according to the old hierarchical system; it was the supplier of breeder seed to most prefecture seed companies in the province and the official quality control laboratory was still managed by GSC. However, as a participant in the ASSP project the provincial government plans to accomplish the establishment of an official laboratory outside GSC by late 1995 or early 1996; buildings have been constructed and they are awaiting delivery of the laboratory equipment. 24. There are 97 seed companies in the province; the provincial seed company, 13 prefecture seed companies, and 83 county seed companies. A number of the prefecture and county companies have already moved to a more commercialized system and are marketing seed in the interregional trade. GSC originally intended to form a group company with 3 prefecture seed companies and 11 county seed companies to participate in the Project. This, however, would not have accomplished the desired consolidation and efficiencies as every participant would have desired to continue and expand its seed production activity. It was therefore decided and agreed to form a limited liability stock company on the basis of GSC with participation of 5 county seed companies. 25. The newly formed company (GPSC) will have a group of shareholders, electing a Board of Directors, appointing a chairman of the Board, and through this structure superv Lse the management of the company. The company will be
 - 93 - Page 5 of 7 managed by a general manager who would not be a member of the board; this general manager would be assisted by 3 deputies. One deputy general manager will be responsible for seed production and conditioning, one for sales and marketing, and one for finance/administration. Service functions, the quality assurance department and evaluation of new products will report directly to the general manager. 26. The company will operate from its central location in Nanning where it also maintains its foundation seed farm; away from this center there will be 5 seed production locations and one sales office at the border with Vietnam. The production locations will be at PingGuo (Corn), HePu (peanuts and kenaf [dogbane]), and BeiLiu, HeXian, and TianYong (hybrid rice). 27. The shareholders will contribute to the company the right to use certain facilities for the production of seeds; the 5 seed conditioning lines will be installed at these facilities. The shareholders will also make available to GPSC certain personnel during the harvest and conditioning season to allow the company to manage its seed crop and to keep its permanent staff at a minimum. GPSC, however, will have, through its own staff, supervisory responsibility of all seed production operations and will also have the responsibility to service and maintain the seed processing lines. The number of shares held by each shareholder will be determined after the value of the facilities to be contributed has been established. 28. Great responsibility will lie with the department for the evaluation of new varieties as none of the companies joining into GPSC has any proprietary products or research programs or holds any licenses to such products. GPSC therefore must urgently obtain new varieties for testing from both national and international sources and evaluate them at multiple locations throughout the province as well as in the interregional markets. GPSC has been put in contact with potential international sources for new varieties and the implementation of an accelerated testing program for such new products will be one of the benchmark by which this company will be evaluated. 29. In structuring GPSC it was ensured that the strongest of the initial 14 candidates for participation in the group company were selected for the new shareholding company; the intent being that some of the seed production operations of the other companies will become superfluous. These companies would then become agents and/or representatives of the company for marketing its seed products. Initial discussions on this concept have been held with a number of these companies; this, however, can be accomplished successfully only if GPSC proves that it is in a position to supply superior products from a standpoint of genetics and mechanical quality at competitive prices. 30. GPSC will establish its own internal quality assurance department and laboratory; GPSC also will establish a seed quality assurance program and standards to be met. These standards will be above those issued by the official government control offices. A significant task will be to ensure uniform implementation of these standards at all five production/processing locations. This too will be a benchmark by which GPSC will be evaluated throughout the implementation of the project. In order to assist this effort, GPSC will establish small laboratories for quick analyses directly at the processing sites; all seed prepared for sale, however, will have to be checked by the central laboratory in Nanning before that seed can be sold. 31. In rice, Guangxi province produces about 2.5 million ha per year annually in two crops; first crop is planted in January and harvested in June, second crop is planted in July and harvested in December. Thus the time for harvesting/processing a seed crop is extremely short if companies have to operate without carryover seed. Today about 70% of all rice is hybrid; it is projected that by the year 2000 this will have increased to about 85%. At planting rates of 22.5 kg/ha this wiil require about 47,000 t of seed annually. GPSC projects
 - 94 - Annex 3 Page 6 of 7 to supply about 16,000 t of hybrid rice seed by the year 2000, representing a market share of about 21%; however, a significant quantity will also be sold into the interregional market and to Vietnam. This can be accomplished with hybrids of superior performance and seed of superior quality. 32. In corn, Guangxi province produces about 530,000 ha annually, 45% of which is hybrid; it is projected that the use of hybrid seed will increase to about 80% by the year 2000. Planting rates, however, should decrease from the current 45 kg/ha to about 35 kg/ha, resulting in annual seed needs of about 13,000 t. GPSC plans to accomplish sales of about 6,200 t by the year 2000, representing a market share of about 48%. The company plans to accomplish this objective primarily through the improvement of seed quality, thus allowing the farmer to reduce his planting rates; longterm, however, the company also must distinguish itself by offering improved varieties. 33. Guangxi province produces about 190,000 ha of peanuts annually; at planting rates of 225 kg and a four year seed replacement rate, this results in annual seed needs of about 10,700 t. It is projected that the seed replacement rate will change to three years as GPSC will provide a superior product to the farmers; this scenario makes the sales projection of 4,000 t for the year 2000 attainable. 34. In kenaf, the province produces about 4,000 t of seed annually which is mostly sold into the interregional markets. GPSC targets a sales volume of about 3,000 t for the year 2000, primarily by being able to replace other producers which cannot compete with GPSC's seed quality. 35. The buildup of a strong, customer oriented marketing and distribution network will be a prerequisite for GPSC to accomplish its sales objectives. The company will build on the contacts which its shareholders have already established in the interregional markets and consolidate these, it will introduce its own brand, and it will use it close relations with county seed companies to supply its superior products in their markets. Significant market research however will have to be done to identify competitor's strengths and weaknesses and to identify market niches. 36. Significant training and technical assistance will be provided for GPSC to ensure that management is equipped with the knowledge and understanding for the company to accomplish its objectives. Also, monitoring procedures and performance indicators have been identified to measure the companies progress. These will be explained in the summary section. Summary 37. Training and technical assistance for the three pilot companies will be coordinated to meet their needs. Foreign training will be provided for general business management, marketing, and seed quality; local training will also be provided for the afore mentioned as well as for finance, production, and seed plant operations. The accomplishment of these training schedules throughout the implementation phase of the project will be one of the performance indicators by which these companies will be measured during supervision. Technical assistance in the above indicated fields will be provided throughout the first two years of operation. 38. All companies were provided with guidelines for statutes and charters for the establishment of these companies as legal, autonomous entities; draft documents are to be submitted to the Bank prior to negotiation of the Loan. While the company structures as described above appear to be satisfactory, it must yet be ensured that these autonomous structures can actually operate autonomously following implementation of the Project and this will be monitored closely during supervision.
 Annex 3 Page 7 of 7 39. All companies also must supply documentation that certain property on which the seed processing facilities are to be constructed have been transferred to these companies for their exclusive use and that no authority can dictate to these enterprises to alter the intended use or to infringe on it. 40. In order to prepare the pilot companies for a competitive, commercialized environment, they were directed to minimize their spending on social services and to substitute this with higher salaries/wages. The practice of job guarantee is to be discontinued, housing should not be provided by the companies, and the companies are to implement the practice of hiring temporary workers during the peak seasons so that permanent employment and the related expenses can be minimized. 41. Management auconomy will be measured by the ability of company management to establish prices, production targets, purchasing and selling policies, engage in *he import and export of seeds, decide on investments, acquire and transfer assets, establish joint ventures, hire and dismiss employees, manage personnel and set wages and bonuses, and decide on the use of retained earnings. 42. In addition to the above outlined, certain performance indicators were developed by which the companies will be evaluated during the implementation phase of the project. These are: - Obtaining certificates concerning the legal status of the companies and documentation for transfer of assets; - Adhering to the project implementation schedules; - Establishing a system of monitoring expenditures and commitments during project implementation by the time of the project launch workshop; - Achieving training objectives according to schedules; - Establishing company internal quality standards prior to the first seed production season; - Realizing production and sales volumes according to the 5 year schedules; and - Accomplishing the per unit profit margins which were established in the financial calculations by setting prices according to market conditions and controlling production costs accordingly.

 Annex 7 - 139 - Table 1 of 5 CHINA SEED SECTOR COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT Performance Indicators 1. The major objective of this project is to assist the government in developing a viable commercial seed sector, which can not only produce high quality seeds in sufficient quantity and variety to satisfy farmers, needs but also operates through efficient, self-sustained commercial enterprises. The project would assist in the commercialization of the seed sector (a) by helping the government establish a seed policy and a regulatory framework that would provide a conducive environment to enhance the competitiveness of the seed sector and to encourage international cooperation, (b) by assisting in strengthening institutions so that they can provide effective service and technical support to the seed sector and (c) by supporting the modernization and rationalization of selected seed companies. 2. To measure progress made in implementation of the project, important performance indicators were developed for the policy and regulatory, institutional strengthening and commercialization components during project preparation (Annex 7 Table 1). These indicators, would be used to evaluate the progress of the project and, if necessary, to redesign the project during the mid-term review. Policy and Reaulatorv Component: 3. Seed Sector Policy. The MOA is drafting a seed sector policy as part of the National Seed Sector Industrialization Program. The policy aim to (a) establish a modernized seed sector; (b) separate seed administration from seed commercialization; (c) establish an integrated system of production and marketing; (d) change in seed company structure to independent units; (e) open up markets for interprovincial and international trade; and (f) relax price control. The final draft of this seed sector policy would be submitted to the State Council by the end of 1996. 4. Seed Law. The draft seed law is being revised and the seed law drafting group estimates that the new seed law will be ready for submitting to the State Council by the end of 1996. 5. Reform and revision will be made to the following areas: . the varietal registration and release procedure . provisions for labelling seed for sale with seed quality parameters . inspection procedures for labelling for provincial external quality control agencies . provisions for voluntary seed certification schemes . provisions affecting seed marketing, including the licensing of seed marketers. 6. Membership in International Organizations. To commercialize the seed sector, to improve the quality of seed stock and to encourage international cooperation and trade, China needs to be a member of international seed organizations. The two major organizations are the International Union for the Protection of the New Varieties (UPOV) and International Seed Testing Association (ISTA). It is required that a country must have acceptable plant breeder rights
 Annex 7 - 140 - Table 2 of 5 (PBR) legal framework before joining UPOV. It is also required that ISTA testing and laboratory utandards have to be adopted. Substantial work has already been carried out to satisfy these requirements; the initial draft of PBR legislation has been completed and reviewed with experts from UPOV and ISTA. In general, this draft contains the regulations required for conformity with the requirements of UPOV. The next steps for further action are as follows: 7. UPOV. The drafting group for the PBR legal framework will revise the current draft of the regulations, after unofficial advice from UPOV, to ensure that it conforms with the provisions of the 1978 Act of the Convention. A draft apparently conforming to the 1978 Act will then be submitted to the Council of UPOV for advice on conformity. Following informal advice of conformity by the Council, the responsible agency of the Government will seek formal advice from the Council on conformity. 8. The organizations represented on the drafting group will agree on the location, staffing and financing of the PBR office; draft and pass into law implementing regulations for the operation of the office; and draw up and officially publish a list of species to be initially included under the PBR legislation. Then the responsible agency of Government will forward the instrument of accession to the UPOV Council for approval. 9. ISTA The Seed Testing Division (STD) will continue to negotiate with ISTA to resolve the issues that are preventing the Division from forwarding the application for membership and authorization to issue ISTA international certificates. STD will work on these issues and forward the application to ISTA by the end of 1996, if the issues are resolved. Institutional Strenathenina Component. 10. Seed Oualitv Laboratories. Site selection, design of facilities, commencement of construction, and procurement of the equipment for the seed quality testing laboratories in the official quality control agencies and seed companies, will be initiated in the first year of the project. Prior to use of the laboratory facilities, all laboratories will obtain copies of the official rules for seed testing and adequately train staff in their use. 11. External and Internal Oualitv Control Separation. Prior to the start of the project all provinces participating in the project will ensure the separation, in both resources and finances, of their agencies for official external seed quality control from the internal quality control programs of the seed companies. 12. Training. Training of staff for both external and internal quality control will take place equally in Years 1 and 2 of the project. 13. Variety Evaluation Office Facilities. The computers and accessories for the National Variety Evaluation and Registration office. and the small cold seed store specified will be procured in the first year of the project. 14. Ouality Manaaement Workshoios. Workshops to evaluate the impact of the operation of PBR and the seed quality management systems initiated in the project will be organized in the Year 3 and undertaken in Years 4 and 5 of the project. 15. Informal Sector. Two planter box surveys of the quality of seed in the informal seed sector, i.e., seeds saved by farmers or obtained from close neighbors for planting, will be initiated in the first year of the project. The results would be used by the seed companies and the agro-extension stations in improving the quality of conventional seeds. It is expected that by the year 2005, the yield of conventional seeds would be increased by at least 10%.
 Annex 7 - 141 - page 3 of 5 Commercialization Comoonent: 16. Each seed enterprise would develop a Project Key Activities Schedule, which in a bar chart schedule showing key indicators for monitoring project progress (Figure 2). The first year of the project would include establishment of facilities, training of enterprise and project managers and preparation of bidding documents. Some seed production could begin during the first project year, particularly the procurement and propagation of new genetic materials. The majority of civil construction works and equipment procurement would be completed during the second project year, with processing facilities being commissioned before the end of the year. Some project seeds could therefore be processed late in the second year, but most processing and storage systems would not be available for use until the third project year. 17. Production, processing and marketing of seeds has been planned to begin in project year two with 25% production, increasing to 50% in project year three and 75% and 100% in years four and five respectively. The production schedules of some individual enterprises vary slightly from this average schedule, particularly those of enterprises producing seedlings, which wouldhave no sales until project year three. 18. The progress of each enterprise would be evaluated according to the Implementation plan set out in its Key Activities Schedule (Figure 2). 19. In addition, enterprise performance would be evaluated according to the following points: (a) Management. Have the certificates of legal status of companies and documentation for transfer of assets been obtained? Does the manager have autonomy over in management of the business? - (b) Production Targets. Production and sales will be evaluated in comparison to annual targets over a 5-year period. It is expected that by the year 2005, there will be 15% increase in improved seeds available to farmers. (c) InterDrovincial and International Trade. Number of transactions and quantity of sales to other provinces and other countries. By the year 2005, 30% of seed produced would be traded interprovincially. (d) Profits Per-unit profit margins will be evaluated for adequacy. Have prices been set according to market conditions, and have production costs been controlled? (o) Cash Manaaement. Has a system for monitoring expenditures and commitments been established during project implementation prior to the time of the project launch workshop? (f) Trainin. Have training objectives been achieved according to schedules? (g) Oualitv Assurance. Have company internal quality standards been established prior to the first seed production season? Additional Indicators. 20. Additional indicators were developed to monitor the impact of the project in the commercial seed sector and the farm sector as follows: (a) Commercial Sectc: How many seed companies have achieved the objective of becoming efficient, *E.f-uustained and profitable commercial enterprises? How

It in expected that in the Year 2005, at least 50 seed companies would achieve full commercialization. At least 20 international joint v-nture companies would have business in China. (b) Farm sector: What percentage of hybrid and improved conventional *sede are used in crop production? What does the comparison of incremental yield, production and income of farmers in the project areas compared to the situation before the project *how? How much have grain production and farmers' incom increased?

 Annex 8 - 144 - Page 1 of 10 CHINA SEED SECTOR COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT Terms of Reference International Seed Industry Lead Consultant Location. Beijing with some field travel. Duration. Two months, one month during each visit. One month for the workshop. oualifications: The consultant should have formal qualification in agriculture or plant sciences and should have extensive working experience in several countries in seed industry including seed technology, variety testing and release, field inspection and certification and seed testing. The consultant should have working experience in an International Seed Testing Association (ISTA) accredited seed testing station. Working experience in Chinese seed regulations is essential. Duties: Working in cooperation with the Director of the Central PMO, and Seed Division and the Director of the National Agricultural Extension and Services Center for Seed, the consultant shall: - act as the International Lead Consultant for the preparation and implementation of the Seed Sector Commercialization Project including identification of international consultants for the seed regulation and seed enterprise management component. - assist DOA in the preparation of the seed quality assurance implementation system which covers both variety release and official and internal control that is in accordance with the recent institutional restructuring in China, recommendations and supports under the project. - supervise the implementation of the project seed quality assurance component including development of official seed stations and seed company internal quality control laboratories. - design courses to be implemented both by the international and Chinese consultants according to Chinese requirement on variety release, field inspection, seed testing and seed certification and have them endorsed by the Ministry of Agriculture. - coordinate with the International Variety Testing and Seed Testing consultants and local consultants to carry out two 10- day courses, one on seed testing and its management, and another on field inspection, seed sampling and certification. - assist in the organization of the a national workshop on plant variety testing and protection in phase III.
 Annex 8 -145 - Page 2 of 10 CEIINA SEED SECTOR COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT Terms of Reference International Seed Law and PVP Specialist Location. Beijing with some field travel Duration. Two months, one month during each visit. Oualifications: The consultant should have a law degree and formal graduate qualification in agriculture or plant sciences, and have more than 10 year working in the industry in several countries and have experience in seed and plant breeder right legislation, UPOV convention, plant breeding and ISTA accredited seed testing station. Previous developing country and Chinese experience are preferred. Duties: Working in cooperation with the seed law drafting committee and the Plant Variety Protection Drafting Committee, the consultant shall: - review and discuss the draft seed law and plant variety protection regulation taking the Chinese situation into consideration. - provide insight in areas that need improvement in order to facilitate completion of the drafts. - assist in designing a plant variety protection (PVP) implementation system that is appropriate for China. - assist in preparing an initial list of protected species. - assist China in its attempt to join the International Seed Testing Associations (ISTA). - carry out a follow-up visit in the second year to assist in implementation.

Two-person weeks. Oualifications: The consultant should have nationally recognized qualifications for seed testing proficiency and should have more than 8 years of seed analysis experience in a wide range of crops and its staff training and management in an ISTA accredited seed testing laboratory. Duties: Working in cooperation with the National Agricultural Technical Extension and Services Center for seed and the International Lead Consultant, the consultant shall: - develop a training course in seed testing methods. - work with the local consultants to carry out a 10-day training course on seed testing and management.

Beijing with some field travel Duration. Two-person months, one person month each visit. Oualifications: The consultant should have formal qualification in agriculture or plant sciences and should have more than 10-years of working experience in variety testing, release and protection in a wide range of crops. He/she should have experience in staff management and training. Knowdlege in plant breeder right legislation and UPOV Convention is essential. Duties: Working in cooperation with the Director of Central PMO, the Seed Division for variety testing and protection, the International Lead Consultant and Seed Law and PVP consultant, the consultant shall: - assist in the planning and preparation of a variety release and protection implementation system which covers both responsibilities of official seed administration stations and seed companies. - assess and supervise the implementation of the project variety testing and protection component including the development of official seed administration station and information management system. - design and implement training and study tour program according to the Chinese requirements on variety release and protection. - work with the local consultants to carry out a 10-days training course each on variety release and protection. - in cooperation with the lead consultant, prepare programs for the national workshop on plant variety testing and protection in phase III. - carry out a follow-up visit in the second year to assist in the implementation.

Oualifications: The consultant should have formal qualification in agriculture or plant sciences and should have more than 10 years of working experience in the testing of true-to-type and health in vegetatively propagated planting materials in a wide range of crops. Duties: Working in cooperation with the Director of Central PMO and the Director of the National Agricultural Technical Extension and Services Center for Seed and Planting Material Testing and the International Lead Consultant, the consultant shall: - assist in the planning and preparation of a vegetatively propagated planting material testing implementation system at the National Seed Testing Laboratory. - assess the progress in implementation of the project activities including the equipping of the laboratory at the station and information management system. - design and implement training and study tour program according to the Chinese requirements on this component. - carry out a follow up visit in the second year to assist in the implementation.
 - 150 - Annex 8 Page 7 of 10 CHINA SEED SECTOR COMMERCIALIZATION PROJECT TermB of Reference International Seed Business Management Consultant Location. Beijing with some field travel Duration. One-person month Oualifications: The consultant should have formal qualification in agricultural economic or business management discipline, and should have 10 years of seed business management experience at managerial level including marketing, accounting and finance. He/she should also be experience in staff training and management. Previous developing country and Chinese experience are preferred. Duties: In cooperation with the Director of Central PMO and the International Lead Consultant, the consultant shall: - plan, prepare and teach in a two-week seed business management training and workshop. - prepare a course proposal with detailed program for the local training program on seed business management, seed marketing, accounting and finance. - The course should include organization and management of a share-holding company; responsibilities of the management, Board of Directors and shareholders; business planning, organization and financing of a seed production operation; forecasting; personnel management; licensing of proprietary products and product evaluation; pricing and marketing, and rules and regulations in international seed trade, invoicing, record keeping and filling system; and etc. - lecture notes should be provided to the PMO at least a month for translation into Chinese. Documents of all related example should also be provided for translation.

P.M&IMc In cooperation with the Director of Central PMO and the International Lead Consultant, the consultant shall: - plan, prepare and teach in a two-week seed production, conditioning and store management training and workshop. - prepare a course proposal with detailed program for the local training program on seed production, conditioning and store management. - The course should include organization and management of seed production and contracting production, drying, processing and store; personnel management and responsibilities of staff in the different sections, computerized information and records in seed production, conditioning and store and etc. Lecture notes should be provided to the PMO at least a month in advance for translation.

One-person month Oualifications: The consultant should have formal qualification in seed technology or a related discipline, and should have more than 10 years of seed quality control management experience including variety evaluation, field inspection, seed testing and certification at technical and managerial level. He/she should have experience in international rules and regulations in relation to seed quality standards and assurance (ISTA and OECD), and should have some experience in staff training. Previous developing country and Chinese experience are preferred. Duties: In cooperation with the Director of Central PMO and the International Lead Consultant, the consultant shall: - plan, prepare and teach in a two-week seed quality assurance management training and workshop. - prepare a course proposal with detailed program for the local training program on seed quality assurance management. - the course should include organization and management of *eed quality assurance from production to harvesting, drying, processing, storage and marketing; personnel management and responsibilities of staff; computerized information and record keeping in seed quality assurance management; and etc. Lecture notes should be provides to the PMO at least a month in advance for translation into Chinese.

One-person month Oualifications: The consultant should be a professional engineer with specialized in agribusiness or a professional seed technologist with specilaization in seed processing and conditioning. He/she should have extensive experience in seed industry operations with specific demonstrable experience in the layout design and specification of facilities and equipment for processing/conditioning of grain, grain legume, oil seed, fiber crop and vegeatable seeds. Previous developing country and Chinese experience are preferred. Duties: Under the direction of the director of the Central Project Management Office, the consultant will be working with the CPMO procurement unit, and with engineers and specialists from the participating seed companies. He/she would provide - expert advice on the facilities, equipment, accessories and supplies needed for processing/conditioning, - estimated specific quantities and mixes of seeds for each participating seed company, - assist with development of layout design of the facilities, and assist with preparation of the tender documents for procurement, and - expert advice on technical issues during the bidding and selection process, if needed.

doc.abstracts: The main objective of the Seed Sector Commercialization Project is to assist the government in developing a viable commercial seed sector, which can not only produce high quality seeds in sufficient quantity and variety to satisfy farmer needs but also operates through efficient, self-sustained commercial enterprises. The project will consist of the following components: 1) a seed policy and regulatory framework that will enhance the competitiveness of the seed sector and encourage international cooperation; 2) modernization, rationalization and commercialization of selected seed companies; and 3) institutional strengthening in order to provide effective service and technical support to the seed sector.
